The '''Eurovision Song Contest''' ({{lang fr|Concours Eurovision de la chanson}})<ref>{{cite web|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]] |url=http://www.ebu.ch/departments/television/pdf/Winners-Palmares_56-02.pdf |title=Winners of the Eurovision Song Contest |accessdate=26 December 2007 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080528174029/http://www.ebu.ch/departments/television/pdf/Winners-Palmares_56-02.pdf |archivedate=28 May 2008 }}</ref> is an annual international song competition, arranged since 1956 by the [[Eurovision (network)|Eurovision]] broadcasting organisation, with participants representing primarily European countries. Each participating country submits an original song to be performed on [[live television]] and [[Live radio|radio]], then casts votes for the other countries' songs to determine the winner. Based on the [[Sanremo Music Festival]] held in Italy since 1951, Eurovision has been broadcasting every year since its inauguration in 1956, making it the longest-running annual international television contest and one of the world's longest-running television programmes. It is also one of the most watched non-sporting events,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/english/2513.htm|title=Live Webcast|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060525094524/http://www.eurovision.tv/english/2513.htm|archivedate=25 May 2006|accessdate=25 May 2006}}</ref> with audience figures of between 100 million and 600 million internationally.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/archive/2006/05/2008410141723346664.html|title=Finland wins Eurovision contest|date=21 May 2006|work=[[Al Jazeera English]]|accessdate=8 May 2007|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100604025718/http://english.aljazeera.net/archive/2006/05/2008410141723346664.html|archive-date=4 June 2010|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.museum.tv/archives/etv/E/htmlE/eurovisionso/eurovisionso.htm|title=Eurovision Song Contest – International Music Program|last=Murray|first=Matthew|publisher=[[Museum of Broadcast Communications]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050113034609/http://www.museum.tv/Archives/Etv/E/htmlE/eurovisionso/eurovisionso.htm|archivedate=13 January 2005|url-status=dead|accessdate=15 July 2006|df=dmy-all}}</ref> It has been broadcast in several countries that do not compete, such as the United States, Canada, New Zealand, and China. Since 2000, it has been broadcast online via the Eurovision website.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ebu.ch/en/technical/trev/trev_291-editorial.html|title=Webcasting and the Eurovision Song Contest|author=Philip Laven|date=July 2002|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080528091401/http://www.ebu.ch/en/technical/trev/trev_291-editorial.html|archivedate=28 May 2008|url-status=dead|accessdate=21 August 2006}}</ref>
[[Ireland in the Eurovision Song Contest|Ireland]] holds the record for most victories, with seven wins, including four times in five years in 1992, 1993, 1994, and 1996. Under the current voting system, in place since 2016, the [[List of Eurovision Song Contest winners|highest-scoring winner]] is [[Salvador Sobral]] of Portugal who won the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2017|2017 contest]] in [[Kiev]], [[Ukraine]], with 758 points; under the previous system, the highest-scoring winner was [[Alexander Rybak]] of Norway with 387 points in [[Eurovision Song Contest 2009|2009]]. The most recent winner is [[Duncan Laurence]] from the Netherlands who won the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2019|2019 event]] with the song "[[Arcade (song)|Arcade]]". Winning the Eurovision Song Contest provides artists with a local career boost and sometimes long-lasting international success.<ref name="reuters2007">{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/entertainmentNews/idUSSCH28177920070514|title=Serbia's "Prayer" wins Eurovision Song Contest|date=14 May 2007|work=[[Reuters]]|access-date=1 July 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071009021550/http://www.reuters.com/article/entertainmentNews/idUSSCH28177920070514|archive-date=9 October 2007|url-status=live}}</ref> Some of them include [[ABBA]] (winners for Sweden), [[Bucks Fizz]] & [[Lulu (singer)|Lulu]] (winners for the United Kingdom), [[Celine Dion]] (winner for [[Switzerland in the Eurovision Song Contest 1988|Switzerland]]), [[Johnny Logan (singer)|Johnny Logan]] (who won the contest twice for Ireland), [[Dana International]] (for Israel) and [[Lena Meyer-Landrut|Lena]] (who won for Germany).
== Origins and history == {{Further|History of the Eurovision Song Contest}}
As a [[Effects of World War II|war-torn Europe]] was rebuilding itself in the 1950s, the [[European Broadcasting Union]] (EBU) — based in Switzerland — set up an ad hoc committee to search for ways of bringing together the countries of the EBU around a "light entertainment programme".<ref name="bristol">{{cite news|title=Singing out loud and proud|date=17 May 2005|publisher=[[Daily Mail and General Trust]]|work=[[Bristol Evening Post]]|author=Staff|quote=In the mid-1950s, the members of the European Broadcasting Union set up an ad hoc committee to investigate ways of rallying the countries of Europe round a light entertainment programme. The European Broadcasting Union (EBU) was formed on 12 February 1950 by 23 broadcasting organisations from Europe and the Mediterranean at a conference in Devon, United Kingdom. It was on 6 June 1954, that Montreux became the venue for the first transmission by the EBU's Eurovision Network of the Narcissus Festival and its flower-bedecked procession floats. At Monaco, in late January 1955, this committee, chaired by Marcel Bezençon, director general of Swiss Television, came up with the idea of creating a song contest, inspired by the very popular San Remo Festival. The idea was approved by the EBU General Assembly in Rome on 19 October 1955, and it was decided that the first "Eurovision Grand Prix" – so baptised, incidentally, by a British journalist – would take place in spring 1956 at Lugano, Switzerland.}}</ref> At a committee meeting held in Monaco in January 1955 with [[Marcel Bezençon]] of the Swiss television as chairman, the committee conceived the idea (initially proposed by [[Sergio Pugliese]] of the Italian television [[RAI]]) of an international song contest where countries would participate in one television programme to be transmitted simultaneously across all countries of the union.<ref name="bristol" /><ref name="GoldenJubilee">{{cite web|first=Patrick |last=Jaquin |date=1 December 2004 |url=http://www.ebu.ch/en/union/diffusion_on_line/television/tcm_6-8971.php |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040811033906/http://www.ebu.ch/en/union/diffusion_on_line/television/tcm_6-8971.php |url-status=dead |archive-date=11 August 2004 |title=Eurovision's Golden Jubilee |publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]] |accessdate=18 July 2009 }}</ref> The competition was based upon the existing [[Sanremo Music Festival]] held in Italy<ref>{{cite news|work=[[BBC Online]] |year=2003 |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/radio2/eurovision/2003/history |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071224074456/http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio2/eurovision/2003/history/ |archivedate=24 December 2007 |title=History of Eurovision |accessdate=20 July 2006 |url-status=live |df=dmy }}</ref> and was seen as a technological experiment in [[live television]]. In those days it was a very ambitious project to join many countries together in a wide-area international network. Satellite television did not exist and the [[Eurovision Network]] comprised a terrestrial [[Microwave radio relay|microwave network]].<ref name="EBU40years">{{cite web|first=George T. |last=Waters |date=Winter 1994 |url=http://www.ebu.ch/en/technical/trev/trev_262-editorial.html |title=Eurovision: 40 years of network development, four decades of service to broadcasters |publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]] |accessdate=15 July 2006 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060627213443/http://www.ebu.ch/en/technical/trev/trev_262-editorial.html |archivedate=27 June 2006 }}</ref> The concept, then known as "Eurovision Grand Prix", was approved by the EBU General Assembly in a meeting held in Rome on 19 October 1955, and it was decided that the first contest would take place in spring 1956 in Lugano, Switzerland.<ref name="bristol" /> The name "Eurovision" was first used in relation to the EBU's network by British journalist George Campey in the London ''[[Evening Standard]]'' in 1951.<ref name="GoldenJubilee"/>
The first contest was held in the town of [[Lugano]], Switzerland, on 24 May 1956. Seven countries participated—each submitting two songs, for a total of 14. This was the only contest in which more than one song per country was performed: since 1957 all contests have allowed one entry per country. The [[Eurovision Song Contest 1956|1956 contest]] was won by the host nation, Switzerland.<ref name="milestones">{{cite web|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]] |year=2005 |url=http://www.eurovision.tv/english/611.htm |title=Historical Milestones |accessdate=26 May 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060526065558/http://www.eurovision.tv/english/611.htm |archivedate=26 May 2006 |url-status=dead |df=dmy }}</ref>
=== Naming ===
The contest was first known as the "Eurovision Grand Prix" (in English). This "Grand Prix" name was adopted by Germany, Denmark, Norway and the [[Francophone countries]], with the French designation being ''{{lang|fr|Le Grand-Prix Eurovision de la Chanson Européenne}}''.<ref>{{cite web |first=Franck |last=Thomas |year=1999 |url=http://www.eurovision-fr.net/histoire/histoire5659.php |title=Histoire 1956 à 1959 |publisher=eurovision-fr.net |accessdate=17 July 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060502192602/http://www.eurovision-fr.net/histoire/histoire5659.php |archivedate=2 May 2006 |language=fr }}</ref> The "Grand Prix" was dropped in 1973 and replaced with'' {{lang|fr|Concours}}'' (contest) in French and in 2001 with the English name in German, but not in Danish or [[Norwegian language|Norwegian]]. The [[Eurovision (network)|Eurovision network]] is used to carry many news and sports programmes internationally, among other specialised events organised by the EBU.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]] |date=14 June 2005 |url=http://www.ebu.ch/departments/operations/ops.php |title=The EBU Operations Department |accessdate=20 July 2006 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060717185857/http://www.ebu.ch/departments/operations/ops.php |archivedate=17 July 2006 }}</ref> However, in the minds of the public, the name "Eurovision" is most closely associated with the Song Contest.<ref name="EBU40years"/>

== Format ==
The format of the contest has changed over the years, though the basic tenets have always been thus: participant countries submit original songs, performed live on a television programme broadcast across the Eurovision Network by the EBU simultaneously to all countries.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/3712029.stm | work=BBC News | title=Voting fault hits Eurovision heat | date=13 May 2004 | accessdate=2 May 2010 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120411121135/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/3712029.stm | archive-date=11 April 2012 | url-status=live }}</ref> A "country" as a participant is represented by one television broadcaster from that country: typically, but not always, that country's national [[public broadcasting|public broadcasting organisation]]. The programme is hosted by one of the participant countries, and the programme is broadcast from the [[auditorium]] in the host city. During this programme, after all the songs have been performed, the countries then proceed to cast votes for the other countries' songs: nations are not allowed to vote for their own song.<ref name="2009rules"/> At the end of the programme, the song with the most points is declared as the winner. The winner receives, simply, the prestige of having won—although it is usual for a [[trophy]] to be awarded to the winning songwriters, and the winning country is formally invited to host the event the following year.<ref name="milestones"/>
The programme is invariably opened by one or more presenters, welcoming viewers to the show. Between the songs and the announcement of the voting, an interval act is performed.
As national broadcasters join and leave the [[Eurovision (network)|Eurovision]] feed transmitted by the EBU, the EBU/Eurovision [[Station identification|network logo ident]] (not to be confused with the song contest logo) is displayed. The accompanying theme music (used on other Eurovision broadcasts) is the prelude to [[Marc-Antoine Charpentier]]'s ''[[Te Deum (Charpentier)|Te Deum]]''.<ref name="GoldenJubilee"/> Originally, the same logo was used for both the Eurovision network and the European Broadcasting Union, however, they now have two different logos; when the ident is transmitted, it is the Eurovision network logo that appears.
== Participation == {{further|List of countries in the Eurovision Song Contest}}
Eligible participants include primarily Active Members (as opposed to Associate Members) of the [[European Broadcasting Union|EBU]]. Active members are those who are located in states that fall within the [[European Broadcasting Area]], or are [[member states of the Council of Europe]].<ref name="EBUmembership">{{cite web|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|url=http://www.ebu.ch/en/ebu_members/admission/index.php|title=Membership conditions|accessdate=3 February 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120117162540/http://www.ebu.ch/en/ebu_members/admission/index.php|archive-date=17 January 2012|url-status=live}}</ref>
The European Broadcasting Area is defined by the [[International Telecommunication Union]]:<ref name="ITU-R Radio Regulation 2012">{{cite web |publisher=[[International Telecommunication Union]], available from the Spectrum Management Authority of Jamaica |year= 2012 |url= http://www.sma.gov.jm/sites/default/files/publication_files/ITU-R_Radio_Regulations_2012_%202015_%20Article_5_Table%20of%20Frequencies.pdf |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20130816092114/http://sma.gov.jm/sites/default/files/publication_files/ITU-R_Radio_Regulations_2012_%202015_%20Article_5_Table%20of%20Frequencies.pdf |url-status= dead |archive-date= 16 August 2013 |title= ITU-R Radio Regulations 2012–15 |accessdate= 27 May 2013 }}</ref><!-- A new version of the regulation will be approved on the next ITU World Radiocommunication Conference in November 2015: http://www.itu.int/ITU-R/index.asp?category=conferences&rlink=wrc&lang=en -->
{{quote|The "European Broadcasting Area" is bounded on the west by the western boundary of [[International Telecommunication Union region|Region 1]], on the east by the [[meridian 40° East]] of [[Greenwich meridian|Greenwich]] and on the south by the [[parallel 30° North]] so as to include the northern part of Saudi Arabia and that part of those countries bordering the [[Mediterranean]] within these limits. In addition, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Georgia and Ukraine and those parts of the territories of Iraq, Jordan and Syrian Arab Republic lying outside the above limits are included in the European Broadcasting Area.{{efn|name=EBA expanded in 2007|The [[European Broadcasting Area]] was expanded in November 2007 by the World Radiocommunication Conference (WRC-07), also to include Armenia, Azerbaijan and Georgia.<ref name="ITU-R Radio Regulation 2012"/><ref name="ITU-R Radio Regulation 2004">{{cite web|url=http://www.itu.int/dms_pub/itu-s/oth/02/02/S020200001A4501PDFE.pdf|title=ITU-R Radio Regulations – Articles edition of 2004 (valid in 2004–07)|publisher=[[International Telecommunication Union]]|year=2004|access-date=14 May 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171010235726/https://www.itu.int/dms_pub/itu-s/oth/02/02/S020200001A4501PDFE.pdf|archive-date=10 October 2017|url-status=dead|df=dmy-all}}</ref>}}}}
The western boundary of [[ITU region|Region 1]] is defined by a line running from the [[North Pole]] along [[meridian (geography)|meridian]] 10° West of [[Greenwich]] to its intersection with [[circle of latitude|parallel]] 72° North; thence by [[great circle]] arc to the intersection of meridian 50° West and parallel 40° North; thence by great circle arc to the intersection of meridian 20° West and parallel 10° South; thence along meridian 20° West to the [[South Pole]].<ref>{{cite web |publisher=[[International Telecommunication Union]] |date= 8 September 2005 |url= http://life.itu.int/radioclub/rr/art05.htm#Reg |title= Radio Regulations |accessdate= 18 July 2006 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20060502031912/http://life.itu.int/radioclub/rr/art05.htm#Reg |archive-date= 2 May 2006 |url-status= live }}</ref>
Active members include media organisations, whose broadcasts are often made available to at least 98% of households in their own country which are equipped to receive such transmissions.<ref name="EBUmembership"/>
If an EBU Active Member wishes to participate they must fulfil conditions as laid down by the rules of the contest. A separate copy is drafted annually. {{as of|2015}}, this included the necessity to have broadcast the previous year's programme within their country. After Russia's withdrawal from the 2017 event in Ukraine, and Channel 1 Russia's refusal to air the event, there is some confusion as to whether this rule still exists. C1R did enter a song in 2018, which was voted out of the competition at the semi-final.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/entertainment-arts-44074233|title=Eurovision 2018: Second semi-final sees Russia eliminated|last=Todd|first=Lucy|date=May 10, 2018|work=BBC News|access-date=June 10, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180614162340/https://www.bbc.com/news/entertainment-arts-44074233|archive-date=14 June 2018|url-status=live}}</ref>
A common misconception is that Eurovision participants have to be from Europe. However, that's not true, any full EBU member is eligible for participation.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://eurovoix.com/2018/11/23/eurovision-north-african-countries/|title=Jon Ola Sand: "Participation of North African countries in Eurovision is possible|last1=Herbert|first1=Emily|date=23 November 2018|access-date=23 November 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190401192528/https://eurovoix.com/2018/11/23/eurovision-north-african-countries/|archive-date=1 April 2019|url-status=live}}</ref> Furthermore, associate members are eligible for participation since Eurovision 2017, as long as the Eurovision Reference Group approves it (on a case by case basis).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://eurovoix.com/2016/10/19/esc17-wording-changes-regarding-associate-member-participation/|title=ESC'17: Wording changes regarding associate member participation|last1=Granger|first1=Anthony|date=19 October 2016|access-date=23 November 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181123201106/https://eurovoix.com/2016/10/19/esc17-wording-changes-regarding-associate-member-participation/|archive-date=23 November 2018|url-status=live}}</ref> {{as of|2019}}, Australia is the only associate member to have participated.
The broadcaster must have paid the EBU a participation fee in advance of the [[time limit|deadline]] specified in the rules of the contest for the year in which they wish to participate.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://eurovision.tv/about/faq|title=FAQ - Eurovision Song Contest|website=eurovision.tv|access-date=2019-02-08|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190205044019/https://eurovision.tv/about/faq/|archive-date=5 February 2019|url-status=live}}</ref>
Eligibility to participate is not determined by [[geography|geographic]] inclusion within the continent of Europe, despite the "Euro" in "Eurovision" – nor does it have any relation to the [[European Union]]. Several countries geographically outside the boundaries of Europe have competed: [[Israel]], [[Cyprus]] and [[Armenia]] in Western Asia (Cyprus is a member of the [[Council of Europe]] and a [[member state of the European Union]]), since [[Eurovision Song Contest 1973|1973]], [[Eurovision Song Contest 1981|1981]] and [[Eurovision Song Contest 2006|2006]] respectively; Australia since [[Eurovision Song Contest 2015|2015]]<ref>{{cite web |work= Eurovision Song Contest |date= 10 February 2015 |url= http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=australia_to_participate_in_the_2015_eurovision_song_contest |title= Australia to compete in the 2015 Eurovision Song Contest |access-date= 10 February 2015 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20150210191207/http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=australia_to_participate_in_the_2015_eurovision_song_contest |archive-date= 10 February 2015 |url-status= live }}</ref> and Morocco, in North Africa, in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1980|1980 competition]] alone. In addition, several [[List of countries spanning more than one continent|transcontinental countries]] with only part of their territory in Europe have competed: Turkey, since [[Eurovision Song Contest 1975|1975]]; Russia, since [[Eurovision Song Contest 1994|1994]]; Georgia, since [[Eurovision Song Contest 2007|2007]]; and Azerbaijan, which made its first appearance in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2008|2008 edition]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/12068?rss |title=Eurovision Song Contest – Dusseldorf 2011 | News – JESC – Delegation leaders meet for Junior Eurovision 2008 |publisher=Esctoday.com |accessdate=22 May 2011 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080609225517/http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/12068?rss |archivedate=9 June 2008 }}</ref>

== Hosting == {{See also|List of host cities of the Eurovision Song Contest}}
[[File:Opening act 2, ESC 2011.jpg|thumb|Opening act in Düsseldorf in 2011]]
[[File:ESC 2014 Copenhagen semi 1 jury.JPG|thumb|Eurovision Song Contest in Copenhagen 2014]]
Most of the expense of the contest is covered by [[Sponsor (commercial)|commercial sponsors]] and contributions from the other participating nations. The contest is considered to be a unique opportunity for promoting the host country as a tourist destination. In the summer of 2005, Ukraine abolished its normal visa requirement for visitors from the EU to coincide with its hosting of the event.<ref>{{cite news |first= Helen |last= Fawkes |work= [[BBC News Online]] |date= 19 May 2005 |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/music/4561275.stm |title= Ukrainian hosts' high hopes for Eurovision |accessdate= 19 July 2009 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20080412070715/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/music/4561275.stm |archive-date= 12 April 2008 |url-status= live }}</ref>
Preparations for the event start a matter of weeks after the host wins in the previous year, and confirms to the EBU that they intend to—and have the capacity to—host the event.{{Citation needed|date=July 2009}} A host city is chosen—often a national or regional capital city—and a suitable concert venue is identified. The two largest concert venues were [[Parken Stadium|Parken]] in Copenhagen (which held approximately 38,000 people when Denmark hosted in 2001<ref name="milestones"/>) and the [[Esprit Arena]] in Düsseldorf (which held approximately 36,500 people when Germany hosted in 2011). The smallest town to have been hosts was [[Millstreet]] in [[County Cork]], Ireland, in 1993. The village had a population of 1,500<ref>{{cite web |publisher=Republic of Ireland |url=http://www.ria.gov.ie/filestore/publications/English-CORK-_Millstreet-FINALISED.pdf |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080908050648/http://www.ria.gov.ie/filestore/publications/English-CORK-_Millstreet-FINALISED.pdf |archivedate=8 September 2008 |title=General Information on Millstreet |accessdate=17 July 2009 |url-status=dead |df=dmy }}</ref>—although the [[Green Glens Arena]] venue could hold up to 8,000 people.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.millstreet.ie/green%20glens/greenglens.htm|title=Green Glens Arena|work=[[Millstreet|Town of Millstreet]]|accessdate=19 July 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090604045611/http://www.millstreet.ie/green%20glens/greenglens.htm|archive-date=4 June 2009|url-status=live}}</ref>
The hotel and press facilities in the vicinity are always a consideration when choosing a host city and venue.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|date= 12 September 2008|url= http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=1361|title= Reference group meets in Moscow|accessdate= 18 July 2009|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20090605090417/http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=1361|archive-date= 5 June 2009|url-status= live}}</ref> In [[Kiev]] 2005, hotel rooms were scarce as the contest organisers asked the [[Government of Ukraine|Ukrainian government]] to put a block on bookings they did not control themselves through official delegation allocations or tour packages: this led to many people's hotel bookings being cancelled.<ref>{{cite web |first=John |last=Marone |publisher=The Ukrainian Observer |url=http://www.ukraine-observer.com/articles/208/655 |title=Where Do We Put The Foreign Tourists? |accessdate=18 July 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060204201731/http://www.ukraine-observer.com/articles/208/655 |archivedate=4 February 2006 |url-status=dead |df=dmy }}</ref>
=== Host country ===
After the first two contests were hosted by Switzerland and Germany, it was decided that henceforth the winning country would host the contest the next year.<ref name="milestones"/> The winner of the 1957 Contest was the Netherlands, and Dutch television accepted the responsibility of hosting in 1958. In all but five of the years since this rule has been in place, the winning country has hosted the show the following year. The exceptions are:
* {{ESCYr|1960}}—hosted by the [[BBC]] in London when the Netherlands declined due to expense. The UK was chosen to host because it had come second in 1959.<ref name="50yrs"/> * {{ESCYr|1963}}—hosted by the BBC in London when France declined due to expense, as did second- and third-placed Monaco and Luxembourg when offered hosting duties.<ref name="50yrs"/> * {{ESCYr|1972}}—hosted by the BBC in [[Edinburgh]] when Monaco was unable to provide a suitable venue: [[Télé Monte Carlo|Monegasque television]] invited the BBC to take over due to its previous experience.<ref name="50yrs"/> * {{ESCYr|1974}}—hosted by the BBC in [[Brighton]] when Luxembourg declined due to expense. The BBC was becoming known as the host by default, if the winning country declined.<ref name="ESC1974">{{cite web|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]] |url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/by-year/contest?event=290 |title=Eurovision Song Contest 1974 |accessdate=19 July 2009 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110605061122/http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/by-year/contest?event=290 |archivedate=5 June 2011 |df=dmy }}</ref> * {{ESCYr|1980}}—hosted by the [[Nederlandse Omroep Stichting|NOS]] in [[The Hague]] when Israel declined due to expense, having staged the {{ESCYr|1979}} event in Jerusalem, and the fact that the date chosen for the contest (19 April) was [[Yom Hazikaron|Israel's Remembrance Day]] that year. The Dutch offered to host the contest after several other broadcasters (including the BBC) were unwilling to do so.<ref name="50yrs"/> The reluctance of those national broadcasters to stage the contest were due to already having hosted the event during the past couple of years, in addition to the expense involved.
With the invitation of Australia to participate since 2015, it was announced that due to the logistical and financial issues that would occur if Australia were to host,<ref name=AU_EBU_GR>{{cite web|title=Germany will host Eurovision if Australia wins, says Christer Björkman (UPDATED)|url=http://wiwibloggs.com/2015/04/22/germany-hosts-eurovision-australia-wins-christer-bjorkman/91817/|website=Wiwibloggs.com|publisher=Wiwibloggs|accessdate=5 July 2016|date=22 April 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160808093942/http://wiwibloggs.com/2015/04/22/germany-hosts-eurovision-australia-wins-christer-bjorkman/91817/|archive-date=8 August 2016|url-status=live}}</ref> in the event of an Australian victory, the broadcaster [[Special Broadcasting Service|SBS]] will co-host the next contest in a European city in collaboration with an EBU Member Broadcaster of their choice.<ref name=AU_EBU_PR>{{cite web|title=Australia to make Eurovision Song Contest return in 2016|url=https://www3.ebu.ch/news/2015/11/australia-returns-to-eurovision|website=ebu.ch|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|accessdate=3 March 2016|date=17 November 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160306210247/https://www3.ebu.ch/news/2015/11/australia-returns-to-eurovision|archive-date=6 March 2016|url-status=live}}</ref> However, this has yet to happen and since 1981, all contests have been held in the country which won the previous year.
=== Eurovision logo and theme === [[File:Eurovision Song Contest logo.svg|thumb|right|Logo used in 2004–14]]
The former generic logo was introduced for the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2004|2004 Eurovision Song Contest]] in Turkey, to create a consistent visual identity. The host country's flag appears in the heart of the generic logo. Each year of the contest, the host country creates a sub-theme which is usually accompanied and expressed with a sub-logo and slogan. The theme and slogan are announced by the [[European Broadcasting Union|EBU]] and the host country's national broadcaster.
The generic logo was revamped in 2014, ten years after the first generic logo was created. The revamped logo was conducted by lead designer Cornelis Jacobs and his team of Cityzen Agency.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=eurovision_song_contest_logo_evolves|title=Eurovision Song Contest logo evolves|work=[[European Broadcasting Union|EBU]]|first=Jarmo|last=Siim|accessdate=31 July 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140803055657/http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=eurovision_song_contest_logo_evolves|archive-date=3 August 2014|url-status=live}}</ref> The logo was used for the first time in the [[2015 Eurovision Song Contest]], the 60th edition of the contest.

=== Eurovision Week ===
The term "Eurovision Week" is used to refer to the week during which the Contest takes place.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7418045.stm | work=BBC News | title=Serbia in spotlight for Eurovision | date=23 May 2008 | accessdate=2 May 2010 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100421003937/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7418045.stm | archive-date=21 April 2010 | url-status=live }}</ref> As it is a live show, the Eurovision Song Contest requires the performers to have perfected their acts in rehearsals for the programme to run smoothly. In addition to rehearsals in their home countries, every participant is given the opportunity to rehearse on the stage in the Eurovision auditorium. These rehearsals are held during the course of several days before the Saturday show, and consequently the delegations arrive in the host city many days before the event. Journalists and fans are also present during the preceding days, and so the events of Eurovision last a lot longer than a few hours of television.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://eurovision.tv/about/in-depth/event-weeks|title=Event weeks - Eurovision Song Contest|website=eurovision.tv|access-date=2019-02-08|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180513002900/https://eurovision.tv/about/in-depth/event-weeks/|archive-date=13 May 2018|url-status=live}}</ref> A number of officially accredited hotels are selected for the delegations to stay in, and shuttle-bus services are used to transport the performers and accompanying people to and from the contest venue.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]] |date=17 March 2008 |url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news/belgrade-2008?id=587 |title=Belgrade 2008 |accessdate=19 July 2009 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080518160711/http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news/belgrade-2008?id=587 |archivedate=18 May 2008 }}</ref>
Each participating broadcaster nominates a Head of Delegation, whose job it is to co-ordinate the movements of the delegate members, and who acts as that country's representative to the EBU in the host city.<ref name="2005rules">{{cite web|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]] |year=2005 |url=http://www.eurovision.tv/searchfiles_english/574.htm |title=Rules of the 2005 Eurovision Song Contest |accessdate=10 February 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060210010517/http://www.eurovision.tv/searchfiles_english/574.htm |archivedate=10 February 2006 |url-status=dead |df=dmy }}</ref> Members of the delegations include performers, lyricists, composers, official press officers and—in the years where songs were performed with a live orchestra—a conductor. Also present if desired is a commentator: each broadcaster may supply their own commentary for their TV and/or radio feed, to be broadcast in each country. The commentators are given dedicated commentary booths situated around the back of the arena behind the audience.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://eurovision.tv/story/commentator-s-guide-to-the-commentators|title=Commentator's guide to the commentators|accessdate=15 May 2011}}{{Better source|date=May 2019}}</ref>
=== Rehearsals and press conferences === [[File:Lena Oslo3.jpg|thumb|right|[[Lena Meyer-Landrut|Lena]], representing Germany, performing [[Satellite (Lena Meyer-Landrut song)|Satellite]] during a rehearsal in 2010]]
Since 2004, the first rehearsals have commenced on the Sunday almost two weeks before the Grand Final. There are two rehearsal periods for each country. The countries taking part in the semi-finals have their first rehearsal over four days from the first Sunday to Wednesday. The second is from Thursday to Sunday. The countries which have already directly qualified for the Grand Final rehearse on the Saturday and Sunday.<ref name="eurovision.tv">[http://www.eurovision.tv/upload/press-downloads/2012/RehearsalSchedule2012/_press_v1.1pdf]{{Dead link|date=March 2016}}</ref>
[[File:2006ch Press Conference.jpg|thumb|left|Switzerland hosting a press conference at Eurovision 2006]]
After each country has rehearsed, the delegation meets with the show's production team in the viewing room. Here, they watch the footage of the rehearsal just performed. At this point the Delegation may make known any special requirements or changes needed for the performance, and request them to the host broadcaster. Following this meeting, the delegation hold a press conference where members of the accredited press may pose them questions.<ref name="RehearsalSchedule">{{cite web|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|year=2008|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/upload/media/ESC2008_rehearsals.pdf|title=Rehearsal Schedule|accessdate=19 July 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081221010818/http://www.eurovision.tv/upload/media/ESC2008_rehearsals.pdf|archive-date=21 December 2008|url-status=live}}</ref> The rehearsals and press conferences are held in parallel; so one country holds its press conference, while the next one is in the auditorium rehearsing. A printed summary of the questions and answers which emerge from the press conferences is produced by the host press office, and distributed to journalists' [[Pigeon-hole messagebox|pigeon-holes]].<ref>{{cite web|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|year=2008|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/interviews-2008?id=944|title=Interviews 2008|accessdate=21 June 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090517084933/http://www.eurovision.tv/page/interviews-2008?id=944|archive-date=17 May 2009|url-status=live}}</ref> However, for the 2020 contest in Rotterdam, pigeon holes will not be used, in an effort to modernise the exchange of information.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://eurovision.tv/about/faq/|title=FAQ - Eurovision Song Contest|last=|first=|date=|website=Eurovision Song Contest|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=}}</ref>
Before each of the semi-finals three dress rehearsals are held. Two rehearsals are held the day before (one in the afternoon and the other in the evening), while the third is held on the afternoon of the live event. Since tickets to the live shows are often scarce, tickets are also sold so the public may attend these dress rehearsals.
The same applies for the final, with two rehearsals on the Friday and the third on Saturday afternoon before the live transmission of the grand final on Saturday evening.<ref name="RehearsalSchedule"/> For both semi-finals and for the final, the second dress rehearsal is also the ''Jury Final'', this is where the jury from each country casts their votes. This means that 50% of the result is already decided before the live contests have taken place.<ref name="eurovision.tv"/>
=== Parties and Euroclub === [[File:Pht-Vugar Ibadov eurovision (35).jpg|thumb|The "Euroclub" in Baku, 2012]]
On the Monday evening of Eurovision Week, a ''Mayor's Reception'' is traditionally held, where the city administration hosts a celebration that Eurovision has come to their city. This is usually held in a grand municipally owned location in the city centre. All delegations are invited, and the party is usually accompanied by live music, complimentary food and drink and—in recent years—[[fireworks]].<ref name="AthensNews">{{cite web|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|date=11 May 2009|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=2560|title=The grand opening reception!|accessdate=19 July 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090514022247/http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=2560|archive-date=14 May 2009|url-status=live}}</ref>
After the semi-final and grand final there are after-show parties, held either in a facility in the venue complex or in another suitable location within the city.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=2793|title=After Show Party: Reactions|accessdate=20 June 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090714103810/http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=2793|archive-date=14 July 2009|url-status=live}}</ref>
A ''Euroclub'' is held every night of the week: this is a Eurovision-themed [[nightclub]], to which all accredited personnel are invited.<ref name="Euroclub">{{cite web|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=2309|title=The EuroClub: Official party venue opened its doors|accessdate=18 July 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090508232451/http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=2309|archive-date=8 May 2009|url-status=live}}</ref>
During the week many delegations have traditionally hosted their own parties in addition to the officially sponsored ones. However, in the new millennium the trend has been for the national delegations to centralise their activity and hold their celebrations in the Euroclub.<ref name="Euroclub"/>
== Rules == {{further|Rules of the Eurovision Song Contest}}
Numerous detailed rules must be observed by the participating nations, and a new version is produced each year, for instance the rules specify various deadlines, including the date by which all the participating broadcasters must submit the final recorded version of their song to the EBU. The rules also cover sponsorship agreements and rights of broadcasters to re-transmit the show. The most notable rules which affect the format and presentation of the contest have changed over the years, and are highlighted here.
=== Live music ===
All vocals must be sung live; no voices are permitted on the backing tracks.<ref name="2009rules"/> In 1999, [[Croatia in the Eurovision Song Contest 1999|the Croatian song]] performed by [[Doris Dragović]] and composed by [[Tonči Huljić]] featured sounds on their backing track which sounded suspiciously like human voices. The Croatian delegation stated that there were no human voices, but only digitally synthesised sounds which replicated vocals. The EBU nevertheless decided that they had broken the spirit of the rules, and docked them 33% of their points total that year for the purpose of calculating their five-year points average for future qualification.<ref name="ESC1999">{{cite web|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/by-year/contest?event=314|title=Eurovision Song Contest 1999|accessdate=21 July 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101231130541/http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/by-year/contest?event=314|archive-date=31 December 2010|url-status=live}}</ref>
From 1956 until 1998, the host country was required to provide a live orchestra. Before 1973, all music had to be played by the host orchestra. From 1973 onwards, pre-recorded, non-vocal backing tracks were permitted—although the host country was still obliged to provide a live orchestra to give participants a choice. If a backing track was used, then all the instruments heard on the track were required to be present on the stage. In 1997 this requirement was dropped.<ref name="50yrs"/>
In 1999 the requirement for a live orchestra was removed: it was left as an optional contribution.<ref name="1999rules"/> The host that year, Israel's [[Israel Broadcasting Authority|IBA]], decided not to use an orchestra to save expenses, and thus 1999 was the first year when all the songs were played as pre-recorded backing tracks (in conjunction with live vocals).{{citation needed|date=May 2018}}
=== Language === {{Main|Languages in the Eurovision Song Contest}}
Each submission must have vocals; purely instrumental music has never been allowed. In the past, competitors have been required to sing in one of their own national languages, but this rule has been changed several times over the years. From 1956 until 1965, there was no rule restricting the languages in which the songs could be sung. In 1966, a rule was imposed stating that the songs must be performed in one of the official languages of the country participating, after Sweden was the first country to not sing in their own language, with opera singer [[Ingvar Wixell]] performing [[Absent Friend|Sweden's 1965 entry]] in English.<ref name="milestones"/> The Swedish-language version of the song was originally selected at [[Melodifestivalen 1965]], but it was later translated into English for the Eurovision contest.
The language restriction continued until 1973, when performers were again allowed to sing in any language they wished.<ref name="ESC1973">{{cite web|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/by-year/contest?event=289|title=Eurovision Song Contest 1973|accessdate=21 July 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110523025310/http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/by-year/contest?event=289|archive-date=23 May 2011|url-status=live}}</ref> Several winners in the mid-1970s took advantage of this: performers from non-English-speaking countries sang in English, including [[ABBA]] in 1974. In 1977, the EBU decided to revert to the national language restriction. However, special dispensation was given to Germany and Belgium as their national selections had already taken place before the decision was made; both countries' entries that year were in English.<ref name="ESC1977">{{cite web|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/by-year/contest?event=293|title=Eurovision Song Contest 1977|accessdate=21 July 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170220022054/http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/by-year/contest?event=293|archive-date=20 February 2017|url-status=live}}</ref> In 1999, the rule was changed again to allow the choice of language once more, which resulted in 12 out of 23 countries, including the United Kingdom, [[Eurovision Song Contest 1999|singing in English that year]].<ref name="ESC1999"/> Belgium entered the 2003 contest with "[[Sanomi]]", a song sung in a [[constructed language]],<ref name="ArtificialLanguages">{{cite web|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=554|title=Ishtar for Belgium to Belgrade!|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|first=Andreas|last=Schacht|date=9 March 2008|accessdate=19 July 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080603193358/http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=554|archive-date=3 June 2008|url-status=live}}</ref> finishing in second place. In 2006, the Dutch entry, "[[Amambanda]]", was sung partly in English and partly in an artificial language.<ref name="ArtificialLanguages"/> In 2008, the Belgian entry, "[[O Julissi]]", was sung in an artificial language.<ref name="ArtificialLanguages"/> In 2011, the Norwegian entry, "[[Haba Haba]]", which was sung in English and [[Swahili language|Swahili]], was the first song to be sung in an African language, apart from Arabic.<ref name="AfricanLanguage">{{cite web|url=http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/16749|title=Norway sends Stella Mwangi to Eurovision 2011|website=EscToday.com|first=Victor|last=Hondal|date=12 February 2011|accessdate=19 February 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110215135659/http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/16749|archive-date=15 February 2011|url-status=live}}</ref>
Since the language rule was abolished in 1999, songs in English have become increasingly common. In 2016, all but three out of 36 semi-finalists had songs in English, with only two (Bosnia and Herzegovina and North Macedonia) performing songs in their native languages, as Austria sent a song in French. In the final, all but three out of 26 contestants had songs in English. After [[Salvador Sobral]]'s win in 2017 with a Portuguese-language song, the 2018 edition saw a significant increase in the use of native languages, with twelve of 43 participants singing in their country's native language (not including Estonia, whose representative opted to sing in Italian).<ref name=EN>{{cite web|url=https://www.euronews.com/2018/05/09/english-song-dominance-on-the-decline-at-eurovision-2018|title=English song dominance on the decline at Eurovision 2018|first1=Antonio|last1=Silva|first2=Chris|last2=Harris|website=[[Euronews]]|date=10 May 2018|access-date=5 June 2019}}</ref> In 2019, nine of the songs were performed totally in different languages, while four others mixed English with their native languages.<ref name=ESClang>{{cite web|url=https://eurovision.tv/story/eurovision-class-of-2019-languages|title=Eurovision Class of 2019: This year's languages|publisher=Eurovision Song Contest|date=5 April 2019|access-date=5 June 2019}}</ref>
=== Voting === {{further|Voting at the Eurovision Song Contest}}
The voting system used in the contest has changed over the years. The current system has been in place since 2016, and is a [[positional voting system]]. Each country awards two sets of 12, 10, 8–1 points to their 10 favourite songs: one from their professional jury of votes of five music professionals and the other from televoting.<ref name="2016 voting">{{cite web|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=biggest_change_to_eurovision_song_contest_voting_since_1975|title=Biggest change to Eurovision Song Contest voting since 1975|date=18 February 2016|accessdate=20 March 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161003180415/http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=biggest_change_to_eurovision_song_contest_voting_since_1975|archive-date=3 October 2016|url-status=live}}</ref>
Historically, a country's votes were decided by an internal jury, but in 1997 five countries (Austria, Switzerland, Germany, Sweden and the United Kingdom) experimented with [[televoting]], giving members of the public in those countries the opportunity to vote ''en masse'' for their favourite songs. The experiment was a success,<ref name="50yrs">{{cite book | last = O'Connor | first = John Kennedy | year = 2005 | title = The Eurovision Song Contest 50 Years The Official History | publisher = Carlton Books Limited | location = London|isbn = 978-1-84442-586-0}}</ref> and from 1998 onwards all countries were encouraged to use televoting wherever possible. Back-up juries are still used by each country, in the event of a televoting failure. Nowadays members of the public may also vote by SMS, in addition to televoting. In every case, every country cannot vote for its own song<ref>{{cite web |url=http://english.people.com.cn/200705/11/eng20070511_373758.html |title=People's Daily Online – Eurovision Song Contest semi-final held in Helsinki |publisher=English.people.com.cn |date=11 May 2007 |accessdate=15 May 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121016234725/http://english.people.com.cn/200705/11/eng20070511_373758.html |archive-date=16 October 2012 |url-status=live }}</ref> From 2013, the public may also vote via a [[mobile app]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=eurovision_song_contest_app_launched|title=Eurovision Song Contest app launched!|publisher=Eurovision.tv|date=7 May 2013|accessdate=3 November 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141103212142/http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=eurovision_song_contest_app_launched|archive-date=3 November 2014|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/static/app/|title=Download the official Eurovision app|publisher=Eurovision.tv|date=3 November 2014|accessdate=3 November 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141103213633/http://www.eurovision.tv/static/app/|archive-date=3 November 2014|url-status=live}}</ref>
