==== Presentation of votes ==== [[File:Eurovision 2004 Scoreboard.jpg|right|thumb|Electronic scoreboard, as [[Johnny Logan (singer)|Johnny Logan]] announces the Irish votes in 2004]]
After the interval act is over, when all the points have been calculated, the presenter(s) of the show call upon each voting country in turn to invite them to announce the results of their vote. Prior to 1994 the announcements were made over [[telephone line]]s; with the audio being piped into the auditorium for the audience to hear, and over the television transmission. However, since and including 1994 the announcements have been presented visually. Often the opportunity is taken by each country to show their spokesperson standing in front of a backdrop which includes a famous place in that country. For example, the French spokesperson might be seen standing in front of the [[Eiffel Tower]] or an Italian presenter might be seen with the [[Colosseum]] in the background.
From 1994 to 1999, some countries did not have their spokesperson in front of a backdrop of a famous place, instead opting to show the spokesperson in the studio or in a famous building, for example when Malta presented their votes from a hotel in the country in 1995, or have them standing behind a blurred image of the famous building or skyline. From the 2000s, new technology meant that the spokespersons could be standing behind a live video of a famous place in that country. There have also been occasions where the backdrop of the spokesperson is not a still image or video, but instead is a slideshow of multiple shots of many of that country's famous buildings.
From 1957 to 1962, the participating countries were called in reverse order of the presentation of their songs, and from 1963 to 2003, they were called in the same order in which their songs had been presented (except for 1974). Since 2004, when semi-finals were introduced, the order of the countries' announcements of votes has changed; and the countries that did not make it to the final each year could also vote. In 2004, the countries were called in alphabetical order (according to their [[ISO 3166-1 alpha-2|ISO codes]]).<ref>{{cite web|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]] |date=12 May 2004 |url=http://www.eurovision.tv/archive_2004/english/1098.htm |title=Eurovision 2004 – Voting Briefing |accessdate=7 May 2005 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050507155415/http://www.eurovision.tv/archive_2004/english/1098.htm |archivedate=7 May 2005 |url-status=dead |df=dmy }}</ref> In 2005, the votes from the non-qualifying semi-finalists were announced first, in their running order on the Thursday night; then the finalists gave their votes in their own order of performance. Between 2006 and 2010, like in 1974, a separate draw was held to determine the order in which countries would present their votes.<ref name="2006draw">{{cite web|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]] |date=21 March 2006 |url=http://www.eurovision.tv/english/2038.htm |title=Results from the draw |accessdate=27 May 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060527003915/http://www.eurovision.tv/english/2038.htm |archivedate=27 May 2006 |url-status=dead |df=dmy }}</ref> From 2011 to 2015, the voting order was determined by the results of a jury the day before the final so as to create as much suspense as possible when the votes were revealed.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=esctoday.com|date=11 May 2011|url=http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/17435|title=Eurovision 2011: Voting order revealed!|access-date=6 June 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110516140447/http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/17435|archive-date=16 May 2011|url-status=live}}</ref> Since 2016, the first country to announce their votes is the country that hosted the previous year, while the last country to announce their votes is the current host.
From 1971 to 1973, each country sent two jurors, who were present at the contest venue (though the juries in [[Eurovision Song Contest 1972|1972]] were locked away in the Great Hall of [[Edinburgh Castle]]) and announced their votes as the camera was trained on them. In [[Eurovision Song Contest 1973|1973]] one of the Swiss jurors presented his votes with flamboyant gestures. This system was retired the next year.<ref name="50yrs"/>
In [[Eurovision Song Contest 1956|1956]] no public votes were presented: a closed jury simply announced that Switzerland had won.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/by-year/contest?event=273|title=Eurovision Song Contest 1956|work=Eurovision.tv|access-date=19 July 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161231055819/http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/by-year/contest?event=273|archive-date=31 December 2016|url-status=live}}</ref> From 1957 to 1987, the points were displayed on a physical [[scoreboard]] to the side of the stage. As digital graphic technology progressed, the physical scoreboards were superseded in 1988 by an [[Computer graphics|electronic representation]] which could be displayed on the TV screen at the will of the programme's director.<ref>{{cite news|work=[[BBC Online]] |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/radio2/eurovision/mymu/atoz.shtml |title=A to Z of Eurovision |accessdate=9 August 2006 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060427103610/http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio2/eurovision/mymu/atoz.shtml |archivedate=27 April 2006 |url-status=dead |df=dmy }}</ref>
In 2006 the EBU decided to save time during the broadcast—much of which had been taken up with the announcement of every single point—because there was an ever-increasing number of countries voting.<ref name="2006draw"/> Since then, votes from 1 to 7 from each country have been displayed automatically on screen and the remaining points (8, 10 and 12) are read out in ascending order by the spokesperson, culminating with the maximum 12 points. Countries must announce the country names and points in either English or French and the scores are repeated by the contest's presenters in the other language. For this reason, the expression ''{{lang|fr|douze points}}'' when the host or spokesperson states the top score in French is popularly associated with the contest throughout the continent.<ref name="1999rules">{{cite web|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|date=13 October 1998|url=http://www.eurosong.net/archive/esc1999.pdf|title=Rules of the 44th Eurovision Song Contest, 1999|accessdate=18 July 2006|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060723152907/http://www.eurosong.net/archive/esc1999.pdf|archive-date=23 July 2006|url-status=live}}</ref> Since 2016, only the name of the top jury votegetter is announced, with the points awarded to the other 9 countries shown in an on-screen scoreboard during the announcement. In addition, only the jury points are announced by country. The televoting results are announced in aggregate, from lowest-scoring country to highest. In the 2019 contest the televoting results were announced in aggregate in inverse standing order based on the jury votes; starting with Spain (7 points from the juries) and culminating in Sweden (239 points from the juries). After the winner has been announced, the televoting points from the country where the contest is watched from are briefly seen on screen.
==== Ties for first place ====
In {{ESCYr|1969}}, four of the sixteen countries taking part, France, Spain, the Netherlands and the United Kingdom, all tied for first place with 18 points each. There was nothing in the rules to decide an outright winner, so all four were declared joint winners. This caused much discontent among most of the other participating countries, and mass walkouts were threatened. Finland, Norway, Sweden and Portugal did not participate in the 1970 Contest as a protest against the results of the previous year. This prompted the EBU to introduce a tie-break rule.<ref name="ESC1969">{{cite web|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/by-year/contest?event=286|title=Eurovision Song Contest 1969|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|accessdate=23 July 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110523004804/http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/by-year/contest?event=286|archive-date=23 May 2011|url-status=live}}</ref><ref name="ESC1970">{{cite web|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/by-year/contest?event=223|title=Eurovision Song Contest 1970|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|accessdate=23 July 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101231092150/http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/by-year/contest?event=223|archive-date=31 December 2010|url-status=live}}</ref>
The current tie-break procedure was implemented in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2016|2016 contest]]. In the procedure, sometimes known as a [[Issues affecting the single transferable vote#Countback|countback]], if two (or more) countries tie, the song receiving more points from the televote is the winner. If the songs received the same number of televote points, the song that received at least one televote point from the greatest number of countries is the winner. If there is still a tie, a second tie-breaker counts the number of countries who assigned twelve televote points to each entry in the tie. Tie-breaks continue with ten points, eight points, and so on until the tie is resolved. If the tie cannot be resolved after the number of countries which assigned one point to the song is equal, the song performed earlier in the running order is declared the winner, unless the host country performed earlier (in which case the song performed later would be the winner). The tie-break procedure originally applied only to first place ties,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/upload/press-downloads/2015/2014-09-02_2015_ESC_rules_EN_PUBLIC_RULES.pdf|title=Public rules of the 60th Eurovision Song Contest|publisher=European Broadcasting Union|accessdate=1 June 2015|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150430201605/http://www.eurovision.tv/upload/press-downloads/2015/2014-09-02_2015_ESC_rules_EN_PUBLIC_RULES.pdf|archivedate=30 April 2015}}</ref> but since 2008 has been applied to all places.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/by-year/contest?event=1469 |work=Eurovision.tv |title=Eurovision 2008 Final |accessdate=20 May 2014}}</ref>
As of {{CURRENTYEAR}}, the only time since 1969 when two or more countries have tied for first place on total points alone was in {{ESCYr|1991}}, when France and Sweden both totalled 146 points. At that time, there was no televote, and the tie break was to determine which country had received the most sets of twelve points, then ten points, and so on. Both France and Sweden had received four sets of 12 points, but Sweden had received more sets of 10-point scores, they were declared the winners. Had the current predominant tiebreaker been in play, France would have won instead by virtue of receiving points from more overall countries.<ref name="50yrs"/>
=== Broadcasting ===
Each participating broadcaster is required to broadcast the show in its entirety: including all songs, recap, voting and reprise, skipping only the interval act for advertising breaks if they wish.<ref name="2009rules"/> From 1999 onwards, broadcasters who wished to do so were given the opportunity to take more advertising breaks as short, non-essential hiatuses were introduced into the programme.<ref name="1999rules"/> Four major interruptions or preemptions of the contest broadcast have taken place since 1999. The Dutch state broadcaster pulled their broadcast of the 2000 final to provide emergency news coverage of a major incident, the [[Enschede fireworks disaster]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=7723&_t=The+end+of+a+decade%3A+Stockholm+2000|title=The end of a decade: Stockholm 2000|last=Bakker|first=Sietse|date=21 December 2009|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|accessdate=21 December 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110605093702/http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=7723&_t=The+end+of+a+decade:+Stockholm+2000|archive-date=5 June 2011|url-status=live}}</ref> Spain's RTVE delayed their broadcast of the second semi-final in the 2009 Contest, due to the [[2009 Mutua Madrileña Madrid Open|Madrid Open]] tennis tournament.<ref name="abc-delay">{{cite news|url=http://www.abc.es/20090515/gente-tv-radio-programacion/soraya-borde-descalificacion-eurovision-200905150219.html|title=Soraya, al borde de la descalificación en Eurovisión|last=Escartín|first=Javier|date=15 May 2009|newspaper=[[ABC (newspaper)|ABC]]|language=Spanish|accessdate=17 May 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090517061608/http://www.abc.es/20090515/gente-tv-radio-programacion/soraya-borde-descalificacion-eurovision-200905150219.html|archive-date=17 May 2009|url-status=live}}</ref> The Albanian state broadcaster deferred their broadcast of the first semi-final in 2012 to provide emergency news coverage of the [[Qafa e Vishës bus accident]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=59793&_t=albania_to_broadcast_tonights_semi-final_deferred|work=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|title=Albania to broadcast tonights semi-final deferred|accessdate=22 May 2012|date=22 May 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120523161447/http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=59793&_t=albania_to_broadcast_tonights_semi-final_deferred|archive-date=23 May 2012|url-status=live}}</ref>
In 2018, Chinese broadcaster [[Mango TV]] edited the Albanian and Irish songs out of their broadcast of the first semi-final for violations of Chinese broadcast regulations. The Albanian performer had visible tattoos, and the Irish song featured a storyline showing vignettes of a homosexual couple. Eurovision terminated Mango's broadcasting rights when the broadcaster refused to agree to air the second semi-final and the grand final unedited.
==== Archive status ====
The first edition ever of the Eurovision Song Contest in 1956 was broadcast live, but not recorded, so only a sound recording of the radio transmission has survived from the original broadcast.<ref name="Archive">{{cite web|title=Two @Eurovision Contests are missing|url=https://twitter.com/ebu_hq/status/597346588479070208|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|accessdate=15 May 2016|date=10 May 2015}}</ref> The ninth edition in [[Eurovision Song Contest 1964|1964]] hosted by [[DR (broadcaster)|Danmarks Radio]] was recorded on tape, but a fire destroyed the recording, and it is unknown if any other TV station in Europe has another copy.<ref name="Archive"/> Only small portions of the original broadcast and audio from the radio transmission have survived.<ref name="Archive"/>
In late 2011, the EBU had begun archiving all the contests since the first edition in 1956 to be finalised before the 2015 Contest, for the 60th anniversary.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=38943|title=EBU starts Eurovision archive project|last=Siim|first=Jarmo|accessdate=8 October 2011|date=8 October 2013|website=eurovision.tv|publisher=EBU|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140317195624/http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=38943|archive-date=17 March 2014|url-status=live}}</ref> It was later reported that the archive is ready and will be released on the 60th anniversary with making the content available to journalists in broadcast-ready formats while also giving public accessibility to "selected content" through the official Eurovision website.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://escxtra.com/2013/06/archive-to-be-opened-in-time-for-60th-anniversary/ |title=General: Archive to be opened in time for 60th Anniversary |website=escxtra.com |publisher=escXtra |accessdate=4 June 2013 |date=4 June 2013 |last=N. |first=Danny |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130611090959/http://escxtra.com/2013/06/archive-to-be-opened-in-time-for-60th-anniversary/ |archivedate=11 June 2013 }}</ref>{{update inline|date=May 2017}}
==== Political recognition issues ====
In [[Eurovision Song Contest 1978|1978]], hosted in Paris only a month after the [[1978 South Lebanon conflict]], during the performance of the Israeli entry, the Jordanian broadcaster [[JRTV]] suspended the broadcast and showed pictures of flowers. When it became apparent during the later stages of the voting sequence that Israel's song "[[A-Ba-Ni-Bi]]" was going to win the contest, JRTV abruptly ended the transmission.<ref name="50yrs"/> Afterwards, the Jordanian news media refused to acknowledge that Israel had won and announced that the winner was Belgium (who had actually come in 2nd place).<ref>{{cite web|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/by-year/contest?event=294|title=Eurovision Song Contest 1978|accessdate=18 July 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110605063638/http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/by-year/contest?event=294|archive-date=5 June 2011|url-status=live}}</ref> In 1981 JRTV did not broadcast the voting because the name of Israel appeared on the scoreboard.
In 2005, Lebanon intended to [[Lebanon in the Eurovision Song Contest|participate in the contest]]. However, Lebanese law does not allow recognition of Israel, and consequently Lebanese broadcaster [[Télé Liban]] did not intend to transmit the Israeli entry. The EBU informed them that such an act would breach the rules of the contest, and Lebanon was subsequently forced to withdraw from the competition. Their late withdrawal incurred a fine, since they had already confirmed their participation and the deadline had passed.<ref>{{cite news|work=[[BBC News Online]]|date=18 March 2005|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/4362373.stm|title=Lebanon withdraws from Eurovision|accessdate=15 July 2006|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110728133244/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/4362373.stm|archive-date=28 July 2011|url-status=live}}</ref> However, the Eurovision Song Contest albums were still being sold in Lebanese music stores until 2009, with the word Israel erased from the back cover. {{as of|2010}}, the albums were banned completely from sale.{{Citation needed|date=May 2013}}
In 2009, the song "[[We Don't Wanna Put In]]" was selected to represent Georgia. However, the song text was banned by Eurovision as it was interpreted as criticism against [[Prime Minister of Russia]] [[Vladimir Putin]] after the [[Russo-Georgian War]] the previous year. When asked to change the lyrics of the song, the Georgian broadcaster [[Georgian Public Broadcaster|GPB]] withdrew from the 2009 contest.<ref>References are found in "[[We Don't Wanna Put In]]"</ref>
In the {{Escyr|1998}} contest, Dana International was sent to compete to represent Israel to perform the song "Diva." International is a [[transgender]] woman and her victory displayed the notion that Eurovision was a place where it was safe to be openly LGBTQ.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.vox.com/2016/5/14/11667716/eurovision-song-contest-2016-logo-timberlake|title=Eurovision, the world's biggest and best singing competition, explained|last=Beauchamp|first=Zack|date=2016-05-14|website=Vox|language=en|access-date=2019-11-22}}</ref> Eurovision created a queer identity for itself by embracing non-heteronormative performers and their performances. Although most of the European public are accepting of this identity, Russian media has had negative reactions to some of the openly queer productions.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.vox.com/2016/5/14/11667716/eurovision-song-contest-2016-logo-timberlake|title=Eurovision, the world's biggest and best singing competition, explained|last=Beauchamp|first=Zack|date=2016-05-14|website=Vox|language=en|access-date=2019-11-22}}</ref>
=== Other ===
* In the first contest, 1956, there was a recommended time limit of 3{{frac|2}} minutes per song.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/upload/history/1956/56_rules.pdf|title=Reglement du Grand Prix Eurovision 1956 De La Chanson Européenne|accessdate=19 July 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120104171321/http://www.eurovision.tv/upload/history/1956/56_rules.pdf|archive-date=4 January 2012|url-status=live}}</ref> In [[Eurovision Song Contest 1957|1957]], despite protests, [[Corde della mia chitarra|Italy's song]] was 5:09 minutes in duration. This led to a stricter time limit of 3 minutes precisely.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/by-year/contest?event=274|title=Eurovision Song Contest 1957|accessdate=19 July 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120505003135/http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/by-year/contest?event=274|archive-date=5 May 2012|url-status=live}}</ref> Since the three-minute time limit was adopted in 1960, some artists have had songs longer than three minutes, which must be edited down to 3 minutes, though some songs exceed that time by a few seconds. Many of the entries also have longer versions (including different languages) for commercial release, and since the 1990s, some are released in additional remixed versions. * The EBU imposes no restrictions on the nationalities of the performers or songwriters. Individual broadcasters are, however, permitted to impose their own restrictions at their discretion.<ref name="2005rules"/> About a dozen artists have performed more than once in the Contest representing different countries, and some of the winners were not born in the country they represented. * From 1957 to 1970 (in 1956 there was no restriction at all) only soloists and duos were allowed on stage. From 1963, a chorus of up to three people was permitted. Since 1971, a maximum of six performers have been permitted on the stage.<ref name="2005rules"/> * The performance and/or lyrics of a song "must not bring the Contest into disrepute". No lyrics, speeches, gestures of a political or similar nature are permitted. No swearing or unacceptable language is allowed, neither are commercial messages.<ref name="2009rules"/> * Prior to 1990, there was no performer age limit. From 1990 to 2003,<ref>{{cite web |title=Rules of the 2003 Eurovision Song Contest |url=http://www.myledbury.co.uk/eurovision/pdf/esc2003.pdf |access-date=1 May 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161110000103/http://www.myledbury.co.uk/eurovision/pdf/esc2003.pdf |archive-date=10 November 2016 |url-status=live }}</ref> all performers were required to be at least 16 years of age by the end of the year in which the contest was held. In 2004,<ref>{{cite web |title=Rules of the 2004 Eurovision Song Contest |url=http://www.myledbury.co.uk/eurovision/pdf/esc2004.pdf |access-date=1 May 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161110000453/http://www.myledbury.co.uk/eurovision/pdf/esc2004.pdf |archive-date=10 November 2016 |url-status=live }}</ref> this was amended to the current rule, which requires all performers to be at least 16 years of age by the time of the contest. * Live animals are prohibited.<ref name="2009rules"/> * Each artist may perform for only one country per year. * The music and text must not have been published or performed before 1 September of the year before the contest is held. Many countries also have the additional rule that the song shall never have been [[Performance|performed]] before the relevant national Eurovision Contest. Covers, reworked or sampled versions of older songs are not allowed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/upload/press-downloads/2012/ESC_2012_public_version_Rules_ENG.pdf|title=Extracts from the 2012 Eurovision Song Contest rules|work=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|accessdate=20 February 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120321165509/http://www.eurovision.tv/upload/press-downloads/2012/ESC_2012_public_version_Rules_ENG.pdf|archive-date=21 March 2012|url-status=live}}</ref>
== Expansion of the contest == {{further|List of countries in the Eurovision Song Contest}}
[[File:Eurovision participation map.svg|thumb|Participants in the Eurovision Song Contest, coloured by decade of debut]]
[[File:Eurovision Participants 1992.svg|thumb|Regular participants in 1992. [[Yugoslavia]] is coloured in red: 1992 was the last year in which that nation participated under one name.]]
[[File:Regular Participants 1994.svg|thumb|Regular participants in 1994. Changes from 1992 include the addition of Central and Eastern European countries, and the separation of ex-Yugoslavian states.]]
The number of countries participating has steadily grown over time, from seven in 1956 to over 20 in the late 1980s. In 1993, twenty-five countries participated in the competition, including, for the first time, Bosnia-Herzegovina, Croatia and Slovenia, entering independently due to the [[Breakup of Yugoslavia|dissolution of Yugoslavia]].<ref>{{cite web|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/by-year/contest?event=235|title=Eurovision Song Contest 1993|accessdate=25 June 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110605093547/http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/by-year/contest?event=235|archive-date=5 June 2011|url-status=live}}</ref> In the most recent edition in 2019, a total of 41 countries took part, with 26 appearing in the final.
Because the contest is a live television programme, a reasonable time limit must be imposed on the duration of the show. In recent years the nominal limit has been four hours, with the broadcast occasionally over-running.<ref name="1999rules"/>
=== Pre-selections and relegation ===
Since 1993, and following the cessation of the Eastern European [[International Radio and Television Organisation|OIRT network]] and the merger with the EBU, there have been more entries than there is time to reasonably include in a single TV show. Several relegation or qualification systems have been tried to limit the number of countries participating in the contest at one time. Thus the 1993 Contest introduced two new features: first, a pre-selection competition was held in [[Ljubljana]] in which seven [[Eastern Bloc|new countries]] fought for three places in the international competition. Bosnia-Herzegovina, Croatia, Estonia, Hungary, Romania, Slovenia and Slovakia took part in ''[[Kvalifikacija za Millstreet]]''; and the three former Yugoslav republics, Bosnia-Herzegovina, Croatia and Slovenia, qualified for a place in the international final.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/by-year/contest?event=235|title=Eurovision Song Contest 1993|accessdate=22 July 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110605093547/http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/by-year/contest?event=235|archive-date=5 June 2011|url-status=live}}</ref> Also to be introduced that year was "relegation": the lowest-placed countries in the 1993 score table were not invited in 1994, to allow the countries which failed the 1993 pre-selection into the 1994 Contest. The 1994 Contest included—for the first time—Estonia, Romania, Slovakia, Lithuania, Hungary, Poland and Russia.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=European Broadcasting Union|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/by-year/contest?event=309|title=Eurovision Song Contest 1994|accessdate=22 July 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110605095406/http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/by-year/contest?event=309|archive-date=5 June 2011|url-status=live}}</ref>
Relegation continued in 1994 and 1995;<ref>{{cite web|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/by-year/contest?event=310|title=Eurovision Song Contest 1995|accessdate=22 July 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101231063825/http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/by-year/contest?event=310|archive-date=31 December 2010|url-status=live}}</ref> but in 1996 a different pre-selection system was used, in which nearly all the countries participated. Audio tapes of all the songs were sent to juries in each of the countries some weeks before the television show. These juries selected the songs which would be included in the international broadcast.<ref name="ESC1996">{{cite web|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/by-year/contest?event=311|title=Eurovision Song Contest 1996|accessdate=18 July 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101231163933/http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/by-year/contest?event=311|archive-date=31 December 2010|url-status=live}}</ref> Norway, as the host country in 1996 (having won the previous year), automatically qualified and so did not need to go through pre-selection.
One country which failed to qualify in the 1996 pre-selection was Germany. As one of the largest financial contributors to the EBU, their non-participation in the contest brought about a funding issue, which the EBU would have to consider.<ref name="ESC1996"/>
{{Anchor|Big Four|Big Five}}
=== Big Four and Big Five ===
Since 2000, [[France in the Eurovision Song Contest|France]], [[Germany in the Eurovision Song Contest|Germany]], [[Spain in the Eurovision Song Contest|Spain]] and [[United Kingdom in the Eurovision Song Contest|United Kingdom]] have automatically qualified for the final, regardless of their positions on the scoreboard in previous contests, as they are the four biggest financial contributors to the [[European Broadcasting Union|EBU]].<ref name="1999rules"/> These countries became known as the "Big Four". On 31 December 2010, it was announced that [[Italy in the Eurovision Song Contest|Italy]] would compete in the Eurovision Song Contest after a fourteen-year absence and that it would also automatically qualify for the final, joining the other four qualifiers to become the "Big Five".<ref>{{cite web|last=Bakker|first=Sietse|title=43 nations on 2011 participants list|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=22833&_t=43+nations+on+2011+participants+list!|website=Eurovision.tv|accessdate=31 December 2010|date=31 December 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110104061710/http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=22833&_t=43+nations+on+2011+participants+list!|archive-date=4 January 2011|url-status=live}}</ref> Germany became the first and, {{as of|2019|lc=y}}, the only "Big Five" country to win the contest since the rule was made in 2000, when [[Lena Meyer-Landrut]] won the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2010|2010 Contest]]. [[Turkey in the Eurovision Song Contest|Turkey]] withdrew from the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2013|2013 Contest]] with the status of the "Big Five" being one of the reasons cited.<ref>{{cite web|last=Jiandani|first=Sanjay|title=Turkey will not go to Eurovision in Malmö|url=http://www.esctoday.com/40037/turkey-will-not-be-in-malmo/|website=ESCToday|accessdate=14 December 2012|date=14 December 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121217011340/http://www.esctoday.com/40037/turkey-will-not-be-in-malmo/|archive-date=17 December 2012|url-status=live}}</ref> They also did not participate in the following 6 years of contests (2014–19) for similar reasons, as well as stating their opposition to the 50/50 jury and televoting system that began being applied in the final of the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2009|2009 Contest]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Jiandani|first=Sanjay|title=Turkey: TRT confirms non participation in Eurovision 2016|url=http://esctoday.com/105436/turkey-trt-confirms-non-participation-in-eurovision-2016/|website=ESCToday|accessdate=15 May 2016|date=3 November 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160523003912/http://esctoday.com/105436/turkey-trt-confirms-non-participation-in-eurovision-2016/|archive-date=23 May 2016|url-status=live}}</ref>
The Big Four/Five countries pay approximately five to six times the participation fee of a "standard" participating country, effectively subsidizing smaller European broadcasters, thus allowing them to be able to afford entry into the competition. Without the contribution of The Big Five it is estimated that the participation cost for a "standard" country would be double what they currently pay.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Pozzi |first1=Renee |title=The cost of not having the 'Big 4/5' |url=https://www.escdaily.com/the-cost-of-not-having-the-big-45/ |website=ESC DAILY |accessdate=15 May 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160719062541/http://www.escdaily.com/the-cost-of-not-having-the-big-45/ |archive-date=19 July 2016 |url-status=live }}</ref>
It is sometimes discussed whether the Big 5 measure benefits or prejudicates the countries' performances in the contest. Since its creation, countries of the Big Five have placed last in 8 of the latest 15 contests (2003, 2005, 2008, 2010, 2014, 2015, 2016, 2017 and 2019). The only Big 5 country that has never finished last since the introduction of this concept is Italy: since its return in 2011, the country placed in the top 10 seven times out of 9 contests, including four times in the top 5, a third place and twice as the runner up; its worst place was a 21st in 2014. Some measures have been taken by the EBU to give the Big 5 contestants a similar status to those competing at the semi-finals, such as broadcasting snippets of their acts in the semi-final interval.
=== Qualification and semi-finals ===
[[File:Eurovision semifinal qualification rate map.svg|thumb|Each country's qualification rates from 2004 to present]]
From 1997 to 2001, countries qualified for each contest based on the average of their points totals for their entries over the previous five years.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/by-year/contest?event=312|title=Eurovision Song Contest 1997|accessdate=26 June 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110605100759/http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/by-year/contest?event=312|archive-date=5 June 2011|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/by-year/contest?event=266|title=Eurovision Song Contest 2001|accessdate=26 June 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120727061435/http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/by-year/contest?event=266|archive-date=27 July 2012|url-status=live}}</ref> However, there was much discontent voiced over this system because a country could be excluded merely because of poor previous results, which did not take into account how good a fresh attempt might be. The worst example of this was that Bosnia and Herzegovina finished 7th with 86 points in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1999|1999 Contest]], but it wasn't enough to save the country being relegated from taking part in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2000|2000 Contest]]. As a result, the EBU reverted to the older relegation system for the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2002|2002]] and [[Eurovision Song Contest 2003|2003]] contests. Soon, the EBU created what was hoped would be a more permanent solution to the problem. A qualification round, known as the semi-final, was introduced for the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2004|2004 Contest]].<ref>{{cite web|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/by-year/contest?event=9|title=Eurovision Song Contest 2004 Semi-final|accessdate=22 July 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090520011431/http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/by-year/contest?event=9|archive-date=20 May 2009|url-status=live}}</ref> This semi-final was held on the Wednesday during Eurovision Week, and was a programme similar in format to the grand final, whose time slot remained 19:00 UTC on the Saturday. The highest-placed songs from the semi-final qualified for the grand final, while the lower-placed songs were eliminated. From 2005 to 2007, the semi-final programme was held on the Thursday of Eurovision Week.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]] |url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/by-year/contest?event=157 |title=Eurovision Song Contest 2005 Semi-final |accessdate=22 July 2009 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090518200559/http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/by-year/contest?event=157 |archivedate=18 May 2009 }}</ref> In these two shows there was enough time to include all the countries who wished to participate.
The ten highest-placed non-Big Four countries in the "grand final" were guaranteed a place in the following year's grand final, without having to qualify. If, for example, Germany came in the top ten, the eleventh-placed non-Big-Four country would automatically qualify for the next year's grand final.<ref name="2005rules"/> The remaining countries—which had not automatically qualified for the grand final—had to enter the semi-final.<ref name="2005rules"/>
At the 50th annual meeting of the EBU reference group in September 2007, it was decided that, with still more nations entering, starting from the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2008|2008 contest]] onwards ''two'' semi-finals would be held,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ebu.ch/CMSimages/en/PR_ESC%20Semi-Finals_01%2E10%2E07_EN_tcm6-54154.pdf|title=Eurovision Song Contest – Two Semi-finals in 2008|date=1 October 2007|accessdate=18 July 2009|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110607055137/http://www.ebu.ch/CMSimages/en/PR_ESC%20Semi-Finals_01.10.07_EN_tcm6-54154.pdf|archive-date=7 June 2011|url-status=live}}</ref> from each of which one could qualify for the final.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2004/05/16/1084646073107.html | title=Bubble rapt | date=17 May 2004 | work=The Sydney Morning Herald | access-date=22 September 2009 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080316012450/http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2004/05/16/1084646073107.html | archive-date=16 March 2008 | url-status=live }}</ref> From 2008 onwards, the scoreboard position in previous years has not been relevant, and—save for the automatic qualifiers—all participating countries have had to participate in the semi-finals, regardless of their previous year's scoreboard position. The only countries which automatically qualify for the grand final are the host country and the Big Five: France, Germany, Italy, Spain and the United Kingdom, who continue to enjoy their protected status.<ref name="2009rules"/>
In each of the semi-finals the voting is conducted among those countries which participate in that semi-final. With regard to the automatic grand final qualifiers, who do not participate in the semi-finals, a draw is conducted to determine in which semi-final each of them will be allowed to vote. In contrast, ''every'' participating country in a particular year may vote in the Saturday grand final – whether their song qualified for the final or not.
The ten countries which receive the most votes in each semi-final qualify for the grand final. They are announced by the presenters in English and French, in a random order. Full voting results are withheld until after the grand final, whereupon they are published on the EBU's website.<ref name="2009rules"/> To date only two countries have always qualified to the Final since the implementation of the semi-finals system in 2004: Australia and Ukraine.

== Winners == {{further|List of Eurovision Song Contest winners|List of Eurovision Song Contest winning songwriters }} [[File:Eurovision winners map.svg|thumb|upright=1.35|Map showing each country's number of Eurovision wins up to and including 2019.|alt=]]
{{as of|2019}}, {{Esccnty|Ireland}} holds the record for the highest number of wins, having won the contest seven times. {{Esccnty|Sweden}} is second with six wins. {{Esccnty|France}}, {{Esccnty|Luxembourg}}, the {{Esccnty|Netherlands}} and the {{Esccnty|United Kingdom}} are joint third with five wins each. {{Esccnty|Israel}} hold four victories. {{Esccnty|Denmark}} and {{Esccnty|Norway}} have both won three times, six countries have won twice, while 12 countries have won once. A further 24 countries have participated, but have yet to win.
The United Kingdom holds the record for the highest number of runner-up placings, coming in second on no fewer than [[United Kingdom in the Eurovision Song Contest#Contestants|15 occasions]] {{as of|2019|lc=y}}. Germany, Russia, France, Spain and Ireland have four runner-up entries. Norway holds the record for finishing in last place in the final the most times: eleven.
Israel is the only non-European country to win four times.
Croatia is the only country to have never won the contest as its current state, but has provided a winner for a former state - Yugoslavia. In 1989, Yugoslavia won the contest with "[[Rock Me (Riva song)|Rock Me]]" performed by [[Riva (band)|Riva]], who won the Yugoslav selection competition that year representing (along with 2 more acts) the Yugoslav Socialist Republic of Croatia. The 1990 contest was subsequently held in Zagreb, now the capital of Croatia.
The early years of the contest saw many wins for "traditional" Eurovision countries: France, the Netherlands, and Luxembourg. However, the success of these countries has declined in recent decades; France last won in 1977 and Luxembourg, in 1983. The Netherlands, however, won again in 2019. Luxembourg last entered the contest in 1993.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.esctoday.com/3221/luxembourg_never_to_return_to_the_contest/ |title=Eurovision Song Contest – Dusseldorf 2011 | News – 'Luxembourg never to return to the contest' |publisher=Esctoday.com |date=5 September 2008 |accessdate=22 May 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140504001211/http://esctoday.com/3221/luxembourg_never_to_return_to_the_contest/ |archive-date=4 May 2014 |url-status=live }}</ref>
The first years of the 21st century produced numerous first-time winners, from both "new" and long-serving countries who had previously entered numerous times but without victories. Every year from 2001 to 2008 inclusive, a country won for its first time. Estonia was the first post-Soviet country to win the competition in 2001. Latvia won for the first time in 2002. In 2003, Turkey won for the first time. In 2005, {{Esccnty|Greece}} won for the first time, 15 years after the last Southern European country won, i.e. {{Esccnty|Italy}} in 1990; overall the [[Southern Europe|South of Europe]] won the competition only six times (seven if Serbia is included). The 2006 winner was {{Esccnty|Finland}}'s [[Lordi (band)|Lordi]], earning Finland's first win after having entered the contest for 45 years. {{Esccnty|Ukraine}}, on the other hand, did not have to wait so long, winning with only their second entry in [[Eurovision Song Contest 2004|2004]]. Also notably, although not the nation's first win, [[Conchita Wurst]]'s win in 2014 broke a 48-year losing run for {{Esccnty|Austria}}. The contest was won by {{Esccnty|Russia}} in 2008.
{{Esccnty|Serbia}} won the very first year it entered as an independent state, in 2007, with the Serbian-language ballad "[[Molitva]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.b92.net/eng/news/society-article.php?yyyy=2007&mm=05&dd=13&nav_category=113&nav_id=41193 |title=News – Serbia wins Eurovision Song Contest |publisher=B92 |accessdate=15 May 2011 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071122210407/http://www.b92.net/eng/news/society-article.php?yyyy=2007&mm=05&dd=13&nav_category=113&nav_id=41193 |archivedate=22 November 2007 }}</ref> In 2004, {{Esccnty|Serbia and Montenegro}} also almost won the initial year it entered as a competitor state, finishing up second behind Ukraine, also with a [[Lane moje|ballad]] in Serbian language.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Eq7nilnv93cC&pg=PA143&dq=serbia+montenegro+lane+moje+second#v=onepage&q=serbia%20montenegro%20lane%20moje%20second|title=A Song for Europe|work=google.rs|isbn=9780754658795|last1=Raykoff|first1=Ivan|last2=Tobin|first2=Robert Deam|year=2007}}</ref> Other relatively quick winners were {{Esccnty|Latvia}}, who won in 2002, only their third year competing, and Azerbaijan, who won in 2011 in only their fourth year in the competition.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/year|title=By year|work=Eurovision.tv|access-date=20 October 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141007081953/http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/year|archive-date=7 October 2014|url-status=live}}</ref>
When {{Esccnty|Portugal}} won in 2017, they ended a 49-year run of entering without a win, beating {{Esccnty|Finland}}'s previous record of 45 years. {{Esccnty|Cyprus}} now holds this record, with 35 years without a win, achieving their highest score, Second, in 2018, and {{Esccnty|Malta}} is the most successful country without a win, achieving two-second places and two third places.<ref name="History of Eurovision song contest">{{cite web |url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/year |title=History of Eurovision song contest |publisher=Eurovision.tv |date=20 October 2014 |accessdate=20 October 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141007081953/http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/year |archive-date=7 October 2014 |url-status=live }}</ref>
In 2009, {{Esccnty|Norway}} won the contest with 387 points – [[Alexander Rybak]] held the winning title with his song "[[Fairytale (Alexander Rybak song)|Fairytale]]". His performance meant he had the highest total in the history of the competition, becoming the first competitor to score 300 or more points, including 16 maximum scores. This feat was emulated in 2012, when Sweden won with 372 points, but with a new record of 18 maximum scores.<ref name="History of Eurovision song contest"/> In 2015, {{Esccnty|Sweden}} won the contest with 365 points, becoming the first country to ever reach 300 points or more twice while winning both times. {{Esccnty|Russia}} placed second with 303 points, becoming the first country to score more than 300 points without winning.
In 2016, the scoring system was changed, which meant that it was much easier to achieve over 300 points – in fact, the winner – [[Jamala]] of {{Esccnty|Ukraine}}, achieved 534 points, and all of top 9 scored 200 or more points, and 25 of the 26 positions got their highest points ever. This feat was then extended in 2017 when Salvador Sobral beat Ukraine's points record by 224 points, getting 758 points in total, in addition to {{Esccnty|Bulgaria}} beating the same score by 81 points, with a total amount of 615 points. However, had Portugal won under the previous voting system, it would still have had the highest total ever, with 417 points, becoming the first competitor to score 400 or more points, and would have set a new record of 20 maximum scores, beating Norway and Sweden, respectively.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.escxtra.com/2017/05/14/eurovision-2017-old-voting/|title=An Alternate Universe: Eurovision 2017 Under the Old Voting System|date=14 May 2017|website=ESCXTRA|access-date=15 May 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170612015618/https://www.escxtra.com/2017/05/14/eurovision-2017-old-voting/|archive-date=12 June 2017|url-status=live}}</ref>
Since the introduction of the [[Voting at the Eurovision Song Contest#Voting Systems|50/50 voting system]] in 2009, the juries and the voters have disagreed on the winner on five occasions, in [[Eurovision Song Contest 2011|2011]], [[Eurovision Song Contest 2015|2015]], [[Eurovision Song Contest 2016|2016]], [[Eurovision Song Contest 2018|2018]] and [[Eurovision Song Contest 2019|2019]]. [[Azerbaijan in the Eurovision Song Contest 2011|2011 winner Azerbaijan]] won only the televotes (jury votes were won by Italy) and [[Sweden in the Eurovision Song Contest 2015|2015 winner Sweden]] won only the jury votes (televotes were won by Italy). In 2016, [[Ukraine in the Eurovision Song Contest 2016|Ukraine]] did not win either the jury vote or the televote, but won the contest with the highest combined vote. The televote was won by Russia and the jury vote by Australia. In 2018, eventual winner [[Israel in the Eurovision Song Contest 2018|Israel]] won the televote but only came in third with the jury vote (won by Austria). In 2019, [[Netherlands in the Eurovision Song Contest 2019|Netherlands]] placed third with the juries (North Macedonia first, Sweden second) and second with the televote (Norway first). However, The Netherlands had the highest combined vote and thus they won the contest.
===Trophy=== {{Annotated image | image = ESC2014 winner's press conference 17 (crop).jpg | image-width = 290 | image-left = -80 | image-top = -90 | width = 150 | height = 285 | float = right | annotations = | caption = The trophy in 2014 }} Since 2008, the winner has been awarded an official winner's trophy of the Eurovision Song Contest. The trophy is a handmade piece of sandblasted glass in the shape of a 1950s [[microphone]].<ref name="Trophy">{{Cite web|url=https://eurovision.tv/about/trophy/|title=Trophy|website=Eurovision Song Contest|language=en|access-date=31 May 2019}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://kostaboda.co.uk/eurovision-song-contest/|title=Eurovision Crystal Trophy|website=[[Kosta Glasbruk|Kosta Boda]]|language=en|access-date=31 May 2019}}</ref> The songwriters and composers of the winning entry receive smaller versions of the trophy.<ref name="Trophy" /> The original design was created by Kjell Engman of [[Kosta Glasbruk|Kosta Boda]], who specialises in glass art.<ref name="Trophy" />
=== Winning artists ===
There have been a number of Eurovision artists and groups whose careers were directly launched into the spotlight following their win. Notable examples were [[ABBA]], who won the contest for Sweden in 1974 with their song "[[Waterloo (ABBA song)|Waterloo]]", and went on to become one of the [[List of best-selling music artists|most successful pop bands]] in history;<ref name="sfgate1">{{cite news | url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2008/09/12/DDBN12SDVQ.DTL | title=Opening of Sweden's ABBA museum is delayed | date=12 September 2008 | work=The San Francisco Chronicle | access-date=20 May 2019 | archive-url=https://archive.today/20120909051343/http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2008/09/12/DDBN12SDVQ.DTL | archive-date=9 September 2012 | url-status=live }}</ref> the [[French Canadian]] singer [[Céline Dion]], who won the contest for Switzerland in 1988 with the song "[[Ne partez pas sans moi]]", which subsequently helped launch her international career;<ref name="reuters2007"/> and the winners of the 1981 contest, [[Bucks Fizz]] for the United Kingdom with the song "[[Making Your Mind Up]]", which also launched a successful international career.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2015/jul/01/bucks-fizz-abba-bob-stanley-eurovision|title=Bucks Fizz: more than just a Kwik Save Abba|last=Stanley|first=Bob|date=1 July 2015|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2 May 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180503111128/https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2015/jul/01/bucks-fizz-abba-bob-stanley-eurovision|archive-date=3 May 2018|url-status=live}}</ref>
Other artists who have achieved varying degrees of success after winning the contest include <!-- PLEASE NOTE: Before adding any more artists to this list, please discuss the issue on the article's Talk Page first. We are currently excluding winning artists from the last five years. --> [[France Gall]] ("[[Poupée de cire, poupée de son]]", [[Eurovision Song Contest 1965|Luxembourg 1965]]), [[Dana Rosemary Scallon|Dana]] ("[[All Kinds of Everything]]", [[Eurovision Song Contest 1970|Ireland 1970]]), [[Vicky Leandros]] ("[[Après toi]]", [[Eurovision Song Contest 1972|Luxembourg 1972]]), [[Brotherhood of Man]] ("[[Save Your Kisses for Me]]", [[Eurovision Song Contest 1976|United Kingdom 1976]]), and [[Johnny Logan (singer)|Johnny Logan]] (who won twice for Ireland, with "[[What's Another Year]]" in [[Eurovision Song Contest 1980|1980]] and "[[Hold Me Now (Johnny Logan song)|Hold Me Now]]" in [[Eurovision Song Contest 1987|1987]]). As of the 2019 contest, he remains the only artist to have won more than once as a performer. <!-- PLEASE SEE NOTE ABOVE -->
Several other winners were well-known artists who won the contest mid-career after they had already established themselves, including [[Katrina and the Waves]], winners in 1997 with "[[Love Shine a Light]]",<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/news/lloyd-webber-agrees-to-try-to-write-a-winner-for-eurovision-966380.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141028030500/https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/news/lloyd-webber-agrees-to-try-to-write-a-winner-for-eurovision-966380.html |url-status=dead |archive-date=28 October 2014 |work=The Independent |location=London |title=Lloyd Webber agrees to try to write a winner for Eurovision |first=Sadie |last=Gray |date=19 October 2008 |accessdate=2 May 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> [[Lulu (singer)|Lulu]], winner in 1969 with "[[Boom Bang-a-Bang]]", and [[Sandie Shaw]], winner in 1967 with "[[Puppet on a String]]". Women have dominated the contest since its inception, with 38 solo female wins, notably including the first two winners, all four winners in the infamous 1969 contest, and the two entries that initially tied for the win in 1991 before Sweden, represented by Carola, won the tie-breaker and claimed sole victory. A further 11 victories feature women as members of duos or groups, though these are mostly mixed-gender, including ABBA's win in 1974 and Brotherhood of Man in 1976, meaning women have been present on 49 of the 67 total winning entries {{as of|2019|lc=y}}. {{Citation needed|date = August 2017}} The 2017 winner was a solo male performance by [[Salvador Sobral]]. However, his sister and the song's composer [[Luísa Sobral]] joined him for the winner's reprise.
The most recent winner of the contest is [[Duncan Laurence]] who won the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2019|2019 contest]] for The Netherlands.<ref>{{Cite web| url=https://eurovisionworld.com/esc/israel-wins-eurovision-song-contest-2018| title=Netta Barzilai from Israel wins Eurovision Song Contest 2018| date=2018-05-12| access-date=12 May 2018| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180512235106/https://eurovisionworld.com/esc/israel-wins-eurovision-song-contest-2018| archive-date=12 May 2018| url-status=live}}</ref>
== Interval acts and guest appearances == [[File:Michael Flatley cropped.jpg|150px|thumb|Irish dance champion [[Michael Flatley]], was part of one of the most appreciated interval acts, ''[[Riverdance]]'' which made its debut in Dublin 1994]]
Since {{ESCYr|1960}}, the tradition of interval acts between the songs in the competition programme and the announcement of the voting has been established.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|url=https://eurovision.tv/story/star-percussionist-revealed-as-eurovision-interval-act|title=Star percussionist revealed as Eurovision interval act|accessdate=21 May 2019}}</ref><ref name="ESC+_Interval_acts">{{cite web|publisher=esc-plus.com |url=https://www.esc-plus.com/the-definitive-guide-to-eurovision-interval-acts/|title=The definitive guide to Eurovision interval acts |accessdate=21 May 2019}}</ref> Among these acts, there are usually the previous winner, performances devoted to the history of the Eurovision Song Contest, as well as representatives of the traditional music scene of the host country.<ref name="ESC+_Interval_acts"/><ref name="Wiwi_Interval_acts">{{cite web|website=[[Wiwibloggs]]|url=https://wiwibloggs.com/2019/04/09/poll-favourite-eurovision-interval-act/236713/|title=Poll: What is your favourite Eurovision grand final interval act from the past decade? |accessdate=21 May 2019}}</ref> One of the interval performances was the first public appearance of [[Riverdance]], a theatrical show consisting mainly of traditional Irish music and dance, in {{ESCYr|1994}}.<ref>{{cite web |first=Clive |last=Barnes |url=http://www.riverdance.com/htm/theshow/thejourney |title=Riverdance Ten Years on |website=RiverDance|accessdate=27 July 2006 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090522033151/http://www.riverdance.com/htm/theshow/thejourney/|archive-date=22 May 2009 |url-status=dead}}</ref><ref name="HuffPost_Interval_acts">{{cite news|work=[[HuffPost]]|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/entry/eurovision-2017-best-interval-acts_uk_5916c005e4b0031e737dddc0|title=Eurovision 2017: Our Countdown Of The 10 Best Interval Acts Ever|accessdate=21 May 2019}}</ref> Riverdance was later performed as an interval act at both the ''[[Congratulations: 50 Years of the Eurovision Song Contest]]'' (2005) and ''[[Eurovision Song Contest's Greatest Hits]]'' (2015) events.
Interval and opening entertainment has included such acts as pop superstars [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]] ({{ESCYr|2019}}), [[Justin Timberlake]] ({{ESCYr|2016}}), [[Aqua (band)|Aqua]] ({{ESCYr|2001}}) and [[t.A.T.u.]] ({{ESCYr|2009}}), but also violinist [[Vanessa-Mae]] ({{ESCYr|1998}}) and [[world music]] artists [[Mariza]] ({{ESCYr|2018}}) and [[Goran Bregović]] ({{ESCYr|2008}}).<ref>{{cite web|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]] |url=https://eurovision.tv/story/justin-timberlake-makes-world-premiere-live-performance-in-the-eurovision-song-contest|title=Justin Timberlake makes world premiere live performance in the Eurovision Song Contest!|accessdate=21 May 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|newspaper=[[CNN]] |url=https://edition.cnn.com/2019/05/18/europe/madonna-eurovision-israel-scli-intl/index.html|title=Eurovision: Madonna mixes politics with a classic hit during performance|accessdate=21 May 2019}}</ref> The world-renowned [[Cirque du Soleil]] ({{ESCYr|2009}}), [[Alexandrov Ensemble]] ({{ESCYr|2009}}), [[Vienna Boys' Choir]] ({{ESCYr|1967}} and {{ESCYr|2015}}), [[Fire of Anatolia]] ({{ESCYr|2004}}) and ''Prague Theatre of Illuminated Drawings'' ({{ESCYr|1984}}) also performed on the Eurovision stage.<ref name="HuffPost_Interval_acts"/><ref>{{cite web|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union]]|url=https://eurovision.tv/story/cirque-du-soleil-opener-for-the-final|title=Cirque du Soleil!|accessdate=21 May 2019}}</ref> A [[flashmob]]-styled performance with [[Madcon]] performing "[[Glow (Madcon song)|Glow]]", alongside live and taped footage of public outdoor dance events from across Europe, was the interval act for {{ESCYr|2010}}. Other interval acts include recorded footage of the [[Royal Edinburgh Military Tattoo]] ({{ESCYr|1972}}), circus clown [[Charlie Rivel]] ({{ESCYr|1973}}), quick-change artist [[Arturo Brachetti]] ({{ESCYr|1991}}) and mentalist [[Lior Suchard]] ({{ESCYr|2019}}).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://eurovision.tv/story/mentalist-lior-suchard-to-make-special-appearance-at-eurovision-2019|title=Mentalist Lior Suchard to make special appearance at Eurovision 2019|date=1 May 2019|website=eurovision.tv|access-date=24 May 2019}}</ref>
The {{ESCYr|1999}} event in [[Jerusalem]] finished with the three presenters inviting everyone on stage to sing a rendition of the English version of "[[Hallelujah (Milk and Honey song)|Hallelujah]]", the Israeli winner from the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1979|1979 Contest]], as a tribute to the victims of the [[1999 NATO bombing of Yugoslavia|Balkan War]] (particularly [[Serbia and Montenegro|FR Yugoslavia]], which was banned from participation as penalty for the Balkan Wars). == Anniversaries ==
=== Songs of Europe === {{Main|Songs of Europe (1981 concert)}}
In 1981, a concert television programme was held to commemorate the contest's twenty-fifth anniversary. The event, entitled [[Songs of Europe (1981 concert)|Songs of Europe]], took place in [[Mysen]], Norway, featuring nearly all the winners of the contest, from 1956 to 1981. It was hosted by [[Rolf Kirkvaag]] and [[Titten Tei]].
=== Congratulations: 50 Years of the Eurovision Song Contest === {{Main|Congratulations: 50 Years of the Eurovision Song Contest}}
In 2005, the EBU had agreed with the Danish broadcaster, [[DR (broadcaster)|DR]], to produce a programme to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the Eurovision Song Contest. The show, entitled [[Congratulations: 50 Years of the Eurovision Song Contest]] after [[Cliff Richard]]'s {{ESCYr|1968}} [[Congratulations (Cliff Richard song)|entry]] for the United Kingdom, was held in Copenhagen, and featured a competition among fourteen of the most popular songs from the last 50 years of the contest. A telephone vote was held to determine the most popular Eurovision song of all-time, which was won by the ABBA song "[[Waterloo (ABBA song)|Waterloo]]" (winner for Sweden in {{ESCYr|1974}}).<ref>{{cite news| work= [[BBC News Online]]| date= 23 October 2005| url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/music/4366574.stm| title= Abba win 'Eurovision 50th' vote| accessdate= 20 July 2006| archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20061019212102/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/music/4366574.stm| archive-date= 19 October 2006| url-status= live}}</ref> The event was hosted by the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1997|1997 Contest]] winner for the United Kingdom, [[Katrina Leskanich]], and Latvia's representative on its debut at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2000|2000 Contest]], [[Renārs Kaupers]].

=== Musical style and presentation ===
Because the songs play to such a diverse international audience with contrasting musical tastes, and countries want to be able to appeal to as many people as possible to gain votes, this has led to the music of the contest being characterised as a "mishmash of [[power ballads]], ethnic rhythms and [[bubblegum pop]]".<ref name=":0">{{cite news|first=Paul|last=Majendie|date=11 August 2007|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/idUKL1142844820070814|work=[[Reuters]]|title=Edinburgh Fringe show celebrates Eurovision kitsch|accessdate=18 July 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100601071040/http://uk.reuters.com/article/idUKL1142844820070814|archive-date=1 June 2010|url-status=live}}</ref> This well-established pattern, however, was broken in 2006 with Finnish metal band [[Lordi]]'s victory.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eurovisionaustria.com/blog/eurovisions-diamond-day/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150903222919/http://www.eurovisionaustria.com/blog/eurovisions-diamond-day/ |url-status=dead |archive-date=3 September 2015 |title=Eurovision's Diamond Day }}</ref> As Eurovision is a visual show, many performances attempt to attract the attention of the voters through means other than the music, notably elaborate lighting sequences and [[pyrotechnics]]; sometimes leading to bizarre on-stage theatrics and costumes, including the use of revealing dress.<ref name=":1">Paul Allatson, "'[http://www.informaworld.com/smpp/content~content=a776540935?words=allatson&hash=267716188 Antes cursi que sencilla’: Eurovision Song Contests and the Kitsch Drive to Euro-Unity] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090125180218/http://www.informaworld.com/smpp/content~content=a776540935?words=allatson&hash=267716188 |date=25 January 2009 }}," in the Special issue on Creolisation: Towards a Non-Eurocentric Europe, in ''Culture, Theory and Critique'', vol. 48, no. 1 (Spring 2007): 87–98.</ref>
=== Political and geographical voting ===
The contest has long been accused by some of political bias; the perception is that judges and televoters allocate points based on their nation's relationship to the other countries, rather than the musical merits of the songs.<ref>{{cite news |work= [[BBC News Online]] |date= 16 May 2004 |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/south_east/3719157.stm |title= Eurovision votes 'farce' attack |accessdate= 15 July 2006 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20060427085641/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/south_east/3719157.stm |archive-date= 27 April 2006 |url-status= live }}</ref> According to one study of Eurovision voting patterns, certain countries tend to form "clusters" or "cliques" by frequently voting in the same way.<ref name="FennEtAl"/> Another study concludes that as of 2006, [[voting bloc]]s have, on at least two occasions, crucially affected the outcome of the contest.<ref name="Gatherer">Derek Gatherer. "[http://jasss.soc.surrey.ac.uk/9/2/1.html Comparison of Eurovision Song Contest Simulation with Actual Results Reveals Shifting Patterns of Collusive Voting Alliances.] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070505041808/http://jasss.soc.surrey.ac.uk/9/2/1.html |date=5 May 2007 }}", ''Journal of Artificial Societies and Social Simulation'' vol. 9, no. 2. 31 March 2006. Retrieved 14 May 2011.</ref> On the other hand, others argue that certain countries allocate disproportionately high points to others because of similar musical tastes and cultures and because they speak similar languages,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://w.ecares.org/ecare/personal/ginsburgh/papers/153.eurovision.pdf|title=Ginsburgh, Victor and Abdul Noury. 2006. The Eurovision Song Contest Is Voting Political or Cultural?|accessdate=19 April 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150903222919/http://w.ecares.org/ecare/personal/ginsburgh/papers/153.eurovision.pdf|archive-date=3 September 2015|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author1=Spierdjik, Laura|author2=Vellekoop, Michel|date=18 May 2006|url=http://doc.utwente.nl/66198/1/1794.pdf|title=Geography, Culture, and Religion: Explaining the Bias in Eurovision Song Contest Voting|publisher=rug.nl|accessdate=3 June 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150903222920/http://doc.utwente.nl/66198/1/1794.pdf|archive-date=3 September 2015|url-status=live}}</ref> and are therefore more likely to appreciate each other's music. A recent study in the Journal of Artificial Societies and Social Simulation<ref name="Mantzaris et al">Mantzaris, Alexander V., Rein, Samuel R. and Hopkins, Alexander D. "[http://jasss.soc.surrey.ac.uk/21/1/1.html Examining Collusion and Voting Biases Between Countries During the Eurovision Song Contest Since 1957.] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180319213602/http://jasss.soc.surrey.ac.uk/21/1/1.html |date=19 March 2018 }}", ''Journal of Artificial Societies and Social Simulation'' vol. 21, no. 1. 31 January 2018. Retrieved 16 May 2017.</ref> presents a new approach which allows an analysis of the whole time-line of the contest (from 1957 to 2017) to investigate collusion and the cluster blocks which have been changing. It allows the analysis to find collusive associations over time periods where the voting scheme is non-homogeneous. The results show a changing pattern in the collusive tendencies previously discussed. The current research into the analysis of the voting patterns has been used in notable sources, such as the Economist, for investigating whether over 10-year periods such collusion is increasing or decreasing.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Economist|first1=DailyChart|title=Partisanship at Eurovision is becoming more blatant|url=https://www.economist.com/blogs/graphicdetail/2018/05/daily-chart-7|journal=Economist|accessdate=11 May 2018|date=2018-05-11|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180511153023/https://www.economist.com/blogs/graphicdetail/2018/05/daily-chart-7|archive-date=11 May 2018|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Economist|first1=WarableGames|title=Neighbourly voting in the Eurovision Song Contest|url=https://www.economist.com/news/europe/21742117-continents-annual-singing-tournament-becoming-increasingly-partisan-neighbourly-voting|journal=Economist|accessdate=12 May 2018|date=2018-05-12|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180512021846/https://www.economist.com/news/europe/21742117-continents-annual-singing-tournament-becoming-increasingly-partisan-neighbourly-voting|archive-date=12 May 2018|url-status=live}}</ref>
{{multiple image | direction = vertical | width = 475 | footer = Produced using the methods presented in<ref name="Mantzaris et al" /> and<ref name="Mantzaris et al 2018" /> a network of the significant score deviations can be viewed over a time period of interest. | image1 = The collusion between countries in Eurovision 1997 to 2017.png | alt1 = Collusion in Eurovision 1997 to 2017 | caption1 = The collusion between countries in Eurovision 1997 to 2017 | image2 = Mutual neglect of score allocations in the Eurovision 2010 to 2015.png | alt2 = Neglect in Eurovision 2010 to 2015 | caption2 = Mutual neglect of score allocations in the Eurovision 2010 to 2015 }}
As an example, [[Terry Wogan]], the United Kingdom's presenter of Eurovision since 1980 and one of the only three presenters mentioned by name during the contest proper<ref>{{cite episode|title=Eurovision Song Contest 2008|episodelink = Eurovision Song Contest 2008|series=Eurovision Song Contest|serieslink=Eurovision Song Contest|airdate=24 May 2008}}</ref> stood down from [[BBC One]]'s broadcast in [[Eurovision Song Contest 2008|2008]] saying "The voting used to be about the songs. Now it's about national prejudices. We [the United Kingdom] are on our own. We had a very good song, a very good singer, we came joint last. I don't want to be presiding over another debacle".<ref>{{cite web|date=28 November 2015|url=http://www.nme.com/news/eurovision/38821|title=erry Wogan 'very doubtful' about presenting Eurovision again|access-date=28 November 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080815014245/http://www.nme.com/news/eurovision/38821|archive-date=15 August 2008|url-status=live}}</ref>
Another influential factor is the high proportion of [[expatriate]]s and ethnic minorities living in certain countries. Although judges and televoters cannot vote for their own country's entry, expatriates can vote for their country of origin.
The total numbers of points to be distributed by each country are equal, irrespective of the country's population. Thus voters in countries with larger populations have less power as individuals to influence the result of the contest than those voting in smaller countries. For example, San Marino holds the same voting power as Russia despite the vast geographic and population differences between them.
To try to reduce the effect of voting blocs, national juries were re-introduced alongside televoting in the final in 2009: each contributing 50% of the vote.<ref name="juryconfirmed">{{cite web|url=http://esctoday.com/news/read/12655 |title=EBU confirms 50/50 vote for Eurovision Song Contest |last=Viniker |first=Barry |date=8 December 2008 |website=ESCToday |accessdate=8 December 2008 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081211002140/http://www.esctoday.com/news/read/12655 |archivedate=11 December 2008 }}</ref> This hybrid system was expanded in 2010 to also be implemented in the semi-finals.<ref name="Countries">{{cite web|url=http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=7923&_t=Exclusive%3A+39+countries+to+be+represented+in+Oslo|title=Exclusive: 39 countries to be represented in Oslo|last=Bakker|first=Sietse|date=31 December 2009|publisher=[[European Broadcasting Union|EBU]]|accessdate=31 December 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100103100815/http://www.eurovision.tv/page/news?id=7923&_t=Exclusive:+39+countries+to+be+represented+in+Oslo|archive-date=3 January 2010|url-status=live}}</ref> However, since 1994 no country has won two years in a row, and semi-finals have also been won by different countries, until 2012 when Sweden won the second semi-final in 2011 and 2012. Although many of them used to give their 12 points to the same country each year, like Turkey and Azerbaijan, it has been noticed that factors such as the sets of other high votes received (7, 8 or 10 points) and the number of countries giving points to a specific entry, also highly affect the final positions.
An overview of the overall preference between countries that exhibits patterns of high score allocations is a question that appears frequently and recently a new study investigates the question of 'neglect' in the competition. The concept of 'neglect' here is represented by countries which produce patterns of biased low score allocations to certain countries. Together these two patterns provide a better view of the competition's intrinsic country pair biases. Result of such a study are presented in this paper.<ref name="Mantzaris et al 2018">{{Cite journal | doi=10.1007/s42001-018-0020-2|title = Preference and neglect amongst countries in the Eurovision Song Contest| journal=Journal of Computational Social Science| volume=1| issue=2| pages=377–390|year = 2018|last1 = Mantzaris|first1 = Alexander V.| last2=Rein| first2=Samuel R.| last3=Hopkins| first3=Alexander D.}}</ref> From the analysis it can be seen that countries which exhibit these biases do not receive a penalization from other participants and it presents itself as a means to accumulate more points by establishing these partnerships.

* ''[[Sopot International Song Festival]]'' (1961–80, 1984–2003, 2005–09, 2012–14, 2017–), held in [[Sopot]], Poland. * ''[[Östersjöfestivalen]]'' also called ''Baltic Song Contest'' (1967–present), held annually in [[Karlshamn]], Sweden. * ''[[Cân i Gymru]]'' (1969–72, 1974–), held annually in Wales, was intended to be [[BBC Cymru Wales|BBC Cymru]]'s pre-selection show when Wales expressed an interest in participating in the {{ESCYr|1969}} Eurovision Song Contest separately from the rest of the United Kingdom. * ''[[Caribbean Song Festival]]'' (1984–), held annually between members of the [[Caribbean Broadcasting Union]]. * ''[[Festivali i Këngës]]'' (1962–), held annually in [[Tirana]], Albania, has been used to select Albania's entry for the Eurovision Song Contest since 2003. * ''[[Liet International]]'' (2002–), an annual competition between European ethnic minorities and minority language speakers. First held in [[Friesland]]. * ''[[Junior Eurovision Song Contest]]'' (2003–), for European artists under the age of 15. * ''[[Asia Song Festival]]'' (2004–), held annually in South Korea. * ''[[ABU Song Festivals]]'' (2012–), two Asia-Pacific versions, the biennial [[ABU Radio Song Festival]] and the annual [[ABU TV Song Festival]]. * ''[[Turkvision Song Contest]]'' (2013–15, 2019–), an annual competition that launched in December 2013, for countries and [[autonomous region]]s that have [[Turkic peoples|Turkic]] links.<ref>{{cite web|last=Granger|first=Anthony|title=Turkvision a snub at Eurovision?|url=http://eurovoix.com/2013/09/21/turkey-turkvision-a-snub-at-the-ebu/|publisher=Eurovoix.com|accessdate=21 September 2013|date=21 September 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130924082101/http://eurovoix.com/2013/09/21/turkey-turkvision-a-snub-at-the-ebu/|archive-date=24 September 2013|url-status=live}}</ref> * ''[[AfriMusic Song Contest]]'' (2018–), an annual competition with African artists. * ''[[Eurovision Asia Song Contest]]'' (TBD), Asian counterpart with members of the [[Asia-Pacific Broadcasting Union]]. * ''[[American Song Contest]]'' (TBD), upcoming United States counterpart with American artists from across 50 states.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://eurovoix.com/2019/05/15/details-revealed-about-the-american-song-contest/|title=Details Revealed About The American Song Contest|date=15 May 2019|publisher=Eurovoix|last=Granger|first=Anthony|access-date=15 May 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190517191334/https://eurovoix.com/2019/05/15/details-revealed-about-the-american-song-contest/|archive-date=17 May 2019|url-status=live}}</ref> Similar competitions that are no longer held, include:
* ''[[Castlebar Song Contest]]'' (1966–86, 1988), held annually in [[Castlebar]], [[County Mayo]], Ireland. * ''[[Yamaha Music Festival]]'', also called ''[[World Popular Song Festival]]'' (1970–87, 1989), held in Tokyo, Japan. * ''[[OTI Festival]]'' (1972–98, 2000), competed and hosted by Portugal, Spain and the countries of the Americas. Countries could only sing in Spanish and Portuguese. * ''[[Intervision Song Contest]]'' (1977–80, 2008), originally held by the [[Eastern Bloc]] countries of Europe and Finland. Now held by [[Post-Soviet states]] and members of the [[Shanghai Cooperation Organisation]]. * ''[[MGP Nordic]]'' (2002, 2006–09), for artists under the age of 16 in [[Scandinavia]] and Finland. * ''World Oriental Music Festival'' (2005), includes participants from Europe and Asia.{{citation needed|date=May 2018}} * ''[[Bundesvision Song Contest]]'' (2005–15), held annually between the 16 states of Germany.
